title: Active Passive voice in Marathi
content:
In English, we have two voices. ‚ÄúActive voice‚Äù and ‚ÄúPassive voice‚Äù. In Marathi such ‚Äúvoice‚Äù is called ‚Äú‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‚Äù(prayog).
There are three types of ‚Äú‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‚Äù(prayog) in Marathi.
‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó ( kartarI prayog )
‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡•Ä ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó ( karmaNI prayog )
‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó ( bhAve prayog )
‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó ( kartarI prayog ) refers to a sentence construction in which the verb changes according to the subject, which is comparable to the active voice in English.
‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡•Ä ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó ( karmaNI prayog ) refers to a sentence construction in which the verb changes according to the object, which is like the passive voice in English.
‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó ( bhAve prayog ) refers to a sentence construction in which the verb does not change according to either the subject or the object.
Normal sentences in the present and future tense in Marathi are of ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó ( kartarI prayog ) i.e active voice; because verb form is decided as per gender and multiplicity of ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§æ(kartA) i.e. doer of an action.
As we have seen before, in the simple past tense, for ‡§∏‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ï ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§¶ (sakarmak kriyApad ) i.e. for verbs needing ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ (karm) i.e noun; verb form is created as per gender and multiplicity of the noun.
So simple past tense sentences with ‡§∏‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ï ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§¶ (sakarmak kriyApad ) are examples of ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡•Ä ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó ( karmaNI prayog ) i.e. passive voice
But like in English, in Marathi the same sentence can be converted from one voice to another and still convey the same meaning.
In English, both voices are very common in all the tenses. Unlike in Marathi; ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡•Ä ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó ( karmaNI prayog ) and ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó ( bhAve prayog ) are not common in the present and future tense. They are used only in peculiar cases. And rules for sentence formation can look odd.
So, you may skip this lesson altogether without any loss in your Marathi learning.
Those who wish to read further about ‚Äú‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‚Äù(prayog), please note that this lesson just gives basic about ‚Äú‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‚Äù(prayog). There are many more grammatical details. Do refer grammar books if you wish to study it in depth.
Take any simple sentence in present tense it will be in ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó ( kartarI prayog ).
So no need to explain any more about it.

title: Add a question tag
content:
In English, we use ‚ÄúQuestion Tag‚Äù when we want confirmation from another person about some activity.
e.g.
You will come to the movie, won‚Äôt you?
She did not drink milk, did she?
In Marathi also we have the concept of
‚Äúquestion tag‚Äù
. But in Marathi, we
just add word ‚Äú‡§®‡§æ‚Äù(nA) to normal sentence
and pronounce it in the tone of asking the question.

title: Adjectives in Marathi ‡§Æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§†‡•Ä ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§£
content:
Adjectives in Marathi behave the same way as in Hindi. i.e. form of adjective word change as per gender and multiplicity of the noun.
e.g. In Hindi, we say ‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ ‡§ò‡•ã‡§°‡§æ ( kAlA ghoDA), ‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡•Ä ‡§ò‡•ã‡§°‡•Ä ( kAlI ghoDI ), ‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡•á ‡§ò‡•ã‡§°‡•á(kAle ghoDe)
We used form ‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ for ‡§™‡•Å‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡§ø‡§Ç‡§ó-‡§è‡§ï‡§µ‡§ö‡§®, ‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡•Ä for ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§≤‡§ø‡§Ç‡§ó-‡§è‡§ï‡§µ‡§ö‡§® and ‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡•á for ‡§™‡•Å‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡§ø‡§Ç‡§ó-‡§¨‡§π‡•Å‡§µ‡§ö‡§®
Consider other adjective ‡§∏‡§´‡•á‡§¶(saphed). We will say ‡§∏‡§´‡•á‡§¶ ‡§ò‡•ã‡§°‡§æ ( saphed ghoDA), ‡§∏‡§´‡•á‡§¶ ‡§ò‡•ã‡§°‡•Ä ( saphed ghoDI ), ‡§∏‡§´‡•á‡§¶ ‡§ò‡•ã‡§°‡•á(saphed ghoDe)
Here we used ‚Äú‡§∏‡§´‡•á‡§¶‚Äù for all genders and multiplicity.
So the change of form is only applicable to adjective ending with ‡§Ü(A).
This is exactly same in Marathi.

title: Adjectives in Marathi
content:
Like in English we have adjectives in Marathi, to describe more about noun/pronoun.

## Form of adjectives
Adjectives in Marathi behave similarly to Hindi. The form of the adjective changes as per gender and multiplicity of the noun.

For adjectives ending with ‡§Ü (A), different forms are used:
‡§ï‡§æ‡§≥‡§æ (kALa) ‚Äì black (masculine singular)
‡§ï‡§æ‡§≥‡•Ä (kALI) ‚Äì black (feminine singular)
‡§ï‡§æ‡§≥‡•á (kALe) ‚Äì black (neuter/plural)

For adjectives that don't end with ‡§Ü (A), the same form is used for all:
‡§∏‡§´‡•á‡§¶ (saphed) ‚Äì white
‡§ö‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ó‡§≤‡§æ (chAMgalA) ‚Äì good

title: Adjectives made from verb
content:
In English we create adjectives from verb like e.g. speaking doll, moving chair, spoken word, defeated nation. The words ‚Äúspeaking‚Äù,‚Äùspoken‚Äù,‚Äùdefeated‚Äù etc. are adjectives created from verbs ‚ÄúTo Speak‚Äù, ‚ÄúTo Defeat‚Äù etc.
In Marathi also we create such adjectives.

title: Adjectives related to prepositions
content:
We have learnt the prepositions in Marathi as well as adjectives. Let‚Äôs see what happens when these two concepts come together.
There are few adjectives which are derived from the prepositions. Generally, these adjectives are created by adding ‡§ö‡§æ(chA) or ‡§≤‡§æ(lA) to the preposition. Like prepositions, these adjectives are added to ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™ (sAmAnya rUp) form of the noun.

title: Asking Question in Marathi.‡§Æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§†‡•Ä ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡•ç‡§®
content: There are different ways of asking the question in Hindi, and the same ways are followed in Marathi as well.

title: Basic questions and "WH" questions in Marathi
content:
Consider sentences :
Do you go?
Did he go?
Will she speak?
Was he dancing?
These are all basic questions in English. In Marathi basic questions can be formed by adding ‡§ï‡§æ (kA). i.e. by appending ‡§ï‡§æ (kA) to a statement it will be converted to question.
He goes -> Does he go
‡§§‡•ã ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡•ã (to jAto) ->
‡§§‡•ã ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡•ã ‡§ï‡§æ?
( to jAto kA ?)
She went -> did she go?
‡§§‡•Ä ‡§ó‡•á‡§≤‡•Ä (tI gelI ) ->
‡§§‡•Ä ‡§ó‡•á‡§≤‡•Ä ‡§ï‡§æ ?
(tI gelI kA)
They will go -> will they go?
‡§§‡•á ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡•Ä‡§≤ (te jAtIl) ->
‡§§‡•á ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡•Ä‡§≤ ‡§ï‡§æ ?
(te jAtIl kA)
Such questions can also be asked by using the same sentence but just changing the tone. In English as well we do it some times.
e.g You are coming -> You coming ??
‡§§‡•Ç ‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡•ã ‡§Ü‡§π‡•á‡§∏
(tU yeto Ahes )
You told him secret ‚Äì> You told him secret ??
‡§§‡•Ç ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ ‡§∞‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ó‡§ø‡§§‡§≤‡•á‡§∏

title: bolane do karane do ‡§¨‡•ã‡§≤‡§®‡•á ‡§¶‡•ã ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡•á ‡§¶‡•ã type sentences
content:
In Hindi sentences like ‚ÄúLet him play‚Äù, ‚ÄúLet me say‚Äù are said as ‡§â‡§∏‡•á ‡§ñ‡•á‡§≤‡§®‡•á ‡§¶‡•ã ( use khelane do )‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ù‡•á ‡§ú‡§æ‡§®‡•á ‡§¶‡•ã ( mujhe jAne do )
In Marathi such sentence is formed by appending ‚Äú‡§ä ‡§¶‡•á‚Äù( U de) to the verb.
This is an imperative/command statement. So when saying someone with respect you will append ‚Äú‡§ä ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‚Äù (U dyA).
Examples will make it clear

The way you call someone who is of your age or you are friendly with will differ from calling an elder.

title: Combining consonants in Marathi ‡§Æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§†‡•Ä ‡§ú‡•ã‡§°‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∞‡•á
content: Combining consonants in Marathi ‡§Æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§†‡•Ä ‡§ú‡•ã‡§°‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∞‡•á
intro: Learn how two or more consonants combine in Marathi. Half symbol + full symbol = ‡§ú‡•ã‡§°‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∞ (joDAkShar).

blocks.heading: Introduction
blocks.content:
In previous chapters, we have learned pronunciation of the Marathi alphabet. In this lesson let's learn combining consonants in Marathi.

Like in any language, two or more consonants can be combined and pronounced together in Marathi.

**Examples:**
- In the English word "fact" consonants "c" and "t" are pronounced together
- In the English word "Alp" consonants "l" and "p" are pronounced together
- In the English word "plethora" consonants "p" and "l" are pronounced together

In English, we just write consonants one after another to indicate their combination. But in Marathi, we do not just write symbols one after another. There is a little change done in the symbol of the first consonant which is to be pronounced half. So the consonant symbol is also written half. So it is important to learn Marathi writing system for such combined sounds.

Half symbol(s) + full symbol is called **‡§ú‡•ã‡§°‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∞** (joDAkShar)

For each symbol its corresponding "half" is predefined. I have grouped consonants depending on their logic to create "half" symbol.

blocks.heading: Group 1: Symbols with vertical line
blocks.content: Their half-symbol is created by omitting the vertical line.

blocks.heading: Group 1 ‚Äì Full symbol, Half symbol, Example with ‡§µ (v)
Group 2: Slanting line below consonant
blocks.content: Half sound is denoted by giving slanting line below consonant.

blocks.heading: Group 2 ‚Äì Full symbol, Half symbol, Example with ‡§µ (v)
Group 3: Symbol ‡§≥ (L)
blocks.content:
The small vertical line in ‡§≥ is removed to make half-symbol: ‡§≥‡•ç‚Äå

**Examples:** ‡§≥‡•ç‚Äå‡§ï, ‡§≥‡•ç‚Äå‡§¨, ‡§≥‡•ç‚Äå‡§µ

blocks.heading: Group 4: Symbol ‡§ï (k)
blocks.content:
The right side curve is written half and connected together with the next symbol: ‡§ï‡•ç‚Äå

**Examples:** ‡§ï‡•ç‡§µ, ‡§ï‡•ç‡§™, ‡§ï‡•ç‡§≤, ‡§ï‡•ç‡§®

blocks.heading: Group 5: Irregular ‚Äì ‡§∞ (r) and ‡§π (h)
blocks.content: ‡§∞ (r) and ‡§π (h) have irregular or multiple half-symbols depending on the other consonant. We will learn them separately in the next chapters.

title: Comparison and degrees of comparison
content:
In English, there are three degrees of comparison viz. positive, comparative and superlative.
Generally, we prefix ‚Äúmore‚Äù and ‚Äúmost‚Äù to an adjective for the comparative and superlative degrees.
Sometimes there are different words to indicate each degree e.g. good-better-best, Bad-worse-worst, tall- taller-tallest, etc.
In Marathi, we do not have this second way of comparison. i.e. adjectives do not change as per degree. Only words indicating degree are prefixed.

title: Comparison in Marathi ‡§§‡•Å‡§≤‡§®‡§æ tulanA
content:
To compare between two-person or objects, In Hindi, we say, ‡§µ‡§π ‡§Æ‡•á‡§∞‡•á‡§∏‡•á ‡§¨‡§°‡§æ ‡§π‡•à (Vah merese baDA hai), ‡§Æ‡•à ‡§â‡§∏‡§∏‡•á ‡§≤‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡§æ ‡§π‡•Ç‡§Ç (mai usase lambA hUM), ‡§µ‡§π ‡§∏‡§¨‡§∏‡•á ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§ü‡§æ ‡§π‡•à (vah sabase moTA hai) etc.

The word ‡§™‡•á‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ(pekShA) is appended to word with whom you are comparing subject.
The words like ‡§ú‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§ / ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï (jAst/adhik) can be used to indicate more. But generally, these words can be omitted.

1) ‡§ü‡§æ‡§ï‡§£‡•á ( TAkaNe)

Main verb+‡§ä‡§®(Un) then form of ‡§ü‡§æ‡§ï‡§£‡•á ( TAkaNe)

1) ‡§ü‡§æ‡§ï‡§£‡•á ( TAkaNe):
This verb is used to indicate that a person is not interested or ready to take action and still he is doing or being asked to do the activity.
Sentence structure is:

title: Exceptional Verbs in Marathi which change in past tense form
content: Exceptional Verbs in Marathi which change in past tense form
intro: Some verbs change themselves before creating past tense form. As past tense is the base of Perfect tenses, it is important to know these forms.

blocks.heading: Introduction
blocks.content:
By now we have studied many grammar concepts including tense. The forms of the verb in simple past tense are the base of perfect tenses and other phrases. We have also observed that few verbs behave differently when their past tense form is created.

As per rule we append ‡§≤‡•ã(lo) to verb for "I". e.g. ‡§¨‡•ã‡§≤(bol)+‡§≤‡•ã(lo)=‡§¨‡•ã‡§≤‡§≤‡•ã(bolalo), ‡§π‡§∏(has)+‡§≤‡•ã(lo)=‡§π‡§∏‡§≤‡•ã(hasalo). So I spoke -> ‡§Æ‡•Ä ‡§¨‡•ã‡§≤‡§≤‡•ã, I laughed -> ‡§Æ‡•Ä ‡§π‡§∏‡§≤‡•ã.

But I went -> ‡§Æ‡•Ä ‡§ó‡•á‡§≤‡•ã(mI gelo). The verb is ‡§ú‡§æ‡§£‡•á(jANe), so we would expect ‡§ú‡§æ(jA)+‡§≤‡•ã(lo)=‡§ú‡§æ‡§≤‡•ã(jAlo). But we appended suffix to ‡§ó‡•á(ge) to make ‡§ó‡•á‡§≤‡•ã(gelo). This is the unusual behavior: verbs which change themselves before creating past tense form.

**For ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡§£‡§£‡•á (mhaNaNe):** Both ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡§ü‡§≤‡§æ (mhaTalA) and ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡§£‡§≤‡§æ (mhaNalA) are used.

title: Exceptional Verbs in Marathi which change in past tense form
content:
By now we have studied many grammar concepts including tense. We have seen the forms of the verb in the simple past tense is base of perfect tenses and other phrases.
We have also observed that few verbs behave differently when their past tense form is created.
As per rule, we append ‡§≤‡•ã(lo) to the verb to create its past tense form for ‚ÄúI‚Äù.
e.g.
I spoke -> ‡§Æ‡•Ä ‡§¨‡•ã‡§≤‡§≤‡•ã ( mI bolalo )
I laughed -> ‡§Æ‡•Ä ‡§π‡§∏‡§≤‡•ã ( mI hasalo )
i.e.
‡§¨‡•ã‡§≤ (bol)+ ‡§≤‡•ã (lo) = ‡§¨‡•ã‡§≤‡§≤‡•ã (bolalo )
‡§π‡§∏(has)+ ‡§≤‡•ã (lo) = ‡§π‡§∏‡§≤‡•ã ( hasalo )
But,
I went -> ‡§Æ‡•Ä ‡§ó‡•á‡§≤‡•ã( mI gelo ).
Now verb is ‚Äú‡§ú‡§æ‡§£‡•á‚Äù(jANe). so we should have said ‡§ú‡§æ(jA) + ‡§≤‡•ã(lo)= ‡§ú‡§æ‡§≤‡•ã (jAlo ).
But we did not say say. We appended suffix to ‡§ó‡•á(ge) to make it ‡§ó‡•á‡§≤‡•ã(gelo).
This is what I want to point out ! The unusual behavior of few verbs. !! The verbs which change themselves before creating past tense form. As past tense form is base of many other tenses and phrases it is important to know such form.

title: Exclamations in Hindi and Marathi
content:
Exclamations or ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§¨‡•ã‡§ß‡§ï are an attractive part of any language. It conveys feeling with added weight. In English, we say ‚ÄúOh My God!!‚Äù , ‚ÄúOh No!! ‚Äù ‚ÄúHow beautiful‚Äù etc. In Hindi, we say ‚Äú‡§π‡•á ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‚Äù(he bhagavAn), ‡§ï‡§ø‡§§‡§®‡§æ ‡§∏‡•Å‡§Ç‡§¶‡§∞ (kitanA suMdar) etc.
The Marathi language also has many exclamations.
The Marathi language has many dialects and different styles of speaking based on the region in Maharashtra. Each dialect can have its special exclamations.
Below I have listed exclamation which is widely used in all the dialects.
Not all Marathi exclamations can have similar words in Hindi and vice-versa. Try to understand the example to know it better.

title: Exclamations in Marathi
content:
Exclamations are an attractive part of any language. It conveys feeling with added weight. In English, we say ‚ÄúOh My God!!‚Äù , ‚ÄúOh No!! ‚Äù ‚ÄúHow beautiful‚Äù etc. The Marathi language also has many exclamations.
The Marathi language has many dialects and different styles of speaking based on the region in Maharashtra. Each dialect can have its special exclamations.
Below I have listed exclamation which is widely used in all the dialects.
Not all Marathi exclamations can have similar words in English and vice-versa. Try to understand the example to know it better.
To Express surprise
1)
‡§ñ‡§∞‡§Ç‡§ö !
( kharaMch )
Similar to ‚ÄúReally !!‚Äù in English
e.g. Really !! I said so -> ‡§ñ‡§∞‡§Ç‡§ö !! ‡§Æ‡•Ä ‡§§‡§∏‡§Ç ‡§¨‡•ã‡§≤‡§≤‡•ã (kharaMch mI tasaM bolalo )

(are !) / ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•á‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ (arechchA!) / ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•á‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ (arechchyA !)
e.g. Hey ! When did you come ? -> ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•á !/ ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•á‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ/ ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•á‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡•Ä ‡§ï‡§ß‡•Ä ‡§Ü‡§≤‡§æ‡§§ ( are !/ arechchA !/ arechchyA ! tumhI kadhI AlAt ? )

(ChaT !)

thU!

title: Express wish in Marathi ‡§á‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§æ ‡§Ü‡§∂‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶
content:
In Hindi, we give blessing like ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§æ‡§® ‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ ‡§≠‡§≤‡§æ ‡§ï‡§∞‡•á(bhagavAn tumhArA bhalA kare), ‡§à‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞ ‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡•á ‡§∏‡§¶‡•ç‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•Ä ‡§¶‡•á (Ishvar tumhe sadbuddhI de).
Or we express wish like ‡§¶‡•Å‡§ï‡§æ‡§® ‡§ú‡§≤‡•ç‡§¶‡•Ä ‡§ñ‡•Å‡§≤ ‡§ú‡§æ‡§Ø‡•á (dukAn jaldI khul jAye), ‡§µ‡§π ‡§Ø‡•á ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§ï‡§∞ ‡§°‡§æ‡§≤‡•á‡§Ç (vah ye kAm kar DAleM)
In Marathi, we say such wishes by appending ‡§ì(o) for singular and ‡§ì‡§§(ot) to plural.
e.g.
for verb do i.e. ‡§ï‡§∞‡§£‡•á(karaNe) forms are ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ã(karo) and ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ã‡§§ (karot)
for verb speak i.e. ‡§¨‡•ã‡§≤‡§£‡•á(bolaNe) forms are ‡§¨‡•ã‡§≤‡•ã(bolo) and ‡§¨‡•ã‡§≤‡•ã‡§§ (bolot)
For verbs not ending with ‡§Ö(a) we append ‡§µ‡•ã(vo) for singular and ‡§µ‡•ã‡§§(vot) for plural.
for verb give i.e.‡§¶‡•á‡§£‡•á (deNe) forms are ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡•ã ( devo ) and ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡•ã‡§§ ( devot )
for verb become i.e ‡§π‡•ã‡§£‡•á ( hoNe ) forms are ‡§π‡•ã‡§µ‡•ã ( hovo ) and ‡§π‡•ã‡§µ‡•ã‡§§ ( hovot )
‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§æ‡§® ‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡•á ‡§Ü‡§∂‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶ ‡§¶‡•á‡§Ç ( bhagavAn tumhe AshirvAd deM )
‡§¶‡•á‡§µ ‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ ‡§Ü‡§∂‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶ ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡•ã ( dev tumhAlA AshirvAd devo )
‡§µ‡§π ‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡•á ‡§Æ‡§¶‡§§ ‡§ï‡§∞‡•á‡§Ç ( vah tumhe madat kareM )
‡§§‡•ã ‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§¶‡§§ ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ã ( to tumhAlA madat karo )

title: Frequently faced pronunciation problems in Marathi (Devanagari)
content: Frequently faced pronunciation problems in Marathi (Devanagari)
intro: Listen to similar-sounding pairs to practice differentiating difficult consonants. Use the speaker buttons to hear each pair.

blocks.heading: Introduction
blocks.content:
In the previous two lessons viz. **Vowels, Consonants in Marathi and their pronunciation** and **Marathi Barakahadi : Symbols for vowels with consonants**, you have seen Marathi (Devanagari) alphabets and their pronunciation.

But sometimes you may face difficulty in differentiating the sounds of two or more consonants. Especially if your native language does not have these consonants, it needs extra effort to sense and create these sounds.

Listening to Marathi a lot is the best way to improve. Also, one of my blog users ‚Äì Vladimir from Russia ‚Äì suggested that it is easy to learn when similar sounding words are spoken together, like a pair.

My other blog user ‚Äì Priscilla from U.K. ‚Äì gave me such a list for ‡§§, ‡§ü, ‡§†, ‡§•, ‡§¶, ‡§¢. So in the corresponding video I have given pronunciation of these pairs. I hope it helps. Let me know if you find it useful and need more such pairs.

1)
Hunger -> ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§ï(bhUk) ; To be hungry -> ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§ï ‡§≤‡§æ‡§ó‡§£‡•á (bhUk lAgaNe)

title: Generalizing words - somewhere somehow anything anybody etc.‡§§‡§∞‡•Ä(tarI) -‡§π‡•Ä(hI)
content:
Consider the
conversation 1)
‚ÄúWho did this mess ?‚Äù
‚ÄúSomeone did it?‚Äù
conversation 2)
‚ÄúHow will you do it?‚Äù
‚ÄúI will manage it somehow‚Äù
When we are not sure about the thing we say ‚Äúsomehow‚Äù, ‚Äúsomewhere‚Äù, ‚Äúanybody‚Äù etc. They are called indefinite pronouns.
In Marathi also such words are present.
In words like
‚Äúsomehow‚Äù, ‚Äúsomewhere‚Äù we prefixed ‚Äúsome‚Äù to words like ‚Äúhow‚Äù, ‚Äúwhere‚Äù

‡§§‡§∞‡•Ä(tarI)
.

‚Äúanyhow‚Äù, ‚Äúanywhere‚Äù we prefixed ‚Äúany‚Äù to words like ‚Äúhow‚Äù, ‚Äúwhere‚Äù

‡§π‡•Ä(hI)

title: Giving instructions formally
content:
We see many signboards saying:
Do not smoke here
Do not use mobile phones
Please maintain silence
Also on different application forms, we see instructions like:
Fill up the form in Block letters.
Enter your preferences.
etc.
All these instructions are nothing but imperative statements(Commands). We have already seen how to prepare imperative sentences.
So translations will be:
Do not smoke here: ‡§ß‡•Ç‡§Æ‡•ç‡§∞‡§™‡§æ‡§® ‡§ï‡§∞‡•Ç ‡§®‡§ï‡§æ (dhoomrapAn karU nakA)

But in Marathi, there is a bit difference in commands and giving instructions formally.

title: Idioms and Phrases in Marathi / different sentence formation in Marathi
content:
Like any language, Marathi has many phrases. Learning phrases, idioms, sayings is an advanced part of the language learning process. Dictionaries & Thesaurus are ideal resources to learn them. So it is not possible to replace them with one or two blog posts. But it is surely possible to introduce to phrases.
So in this lesson, I am enlisting a few phrases & peculiar sentences in which where sentence formation is different in Marathi compared to English. These were either discussed
on facebook group
or asked me over mail.
I will keep updating this lesson as and when I found a good candidate.
Please note that phrases are not translated literally their equivalents are given.
It is assumed that the reader knows basic grammar details about nouns, pronouns, gender, tense, etc. So s/he can take a clue from meaning and make different sentences.
1) To feel sleepy
The phrase ‚Äúto feel sleepy‚Äù is said differently in Marathi. ‚ÄúX is feeling sleepy‚Äù is translated as if saying ‚ÄúSleep is coming to X‚Äù.
I am feeling sleepy -> Sleep is coming to me -> ‡§Æ‡§≤‡§æ ‡§ù‡•ã‡§™ ‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡•á ‡§Ü‡§π‡•á (malA jhop yete Ahe)

title: Learn Prepositions in Marathi
content: Learn Prepositions in Marathi
intro: Prepositions come after the noun in Marathi (postpositions). Use ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™ (sAmAnya rUp) / Oblique case form of pronouns.

blocks.heading: Introduction
blocks.content:
We have finished an important part of grammar i.e. Tenses. Let us move towards different forms of pronouns used for prepositions.

In English "with" is used as "with me", "with him". In Marathi "with" is ‡§¨‡§∞‡•ã‡§¨‡§∞ (barobar).
"with me" -> ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ù‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§¨‡§∞‡•ã‡§¨‡§∞ (mAjhyA barobar)
"with you" -> ‡§§‡•Å‡§ù‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§¨‡§∞‡•ã‡§¨‡§∞ (tujhyA barobar)

The preposition in Marathi comes **after** the noun (postposition). For ‡§Æ‡•Ä we used ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ù‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ, for ‡§§‡•Ç we used ‡§§‡•Å‡§ù‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ. These changed forms are called **‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™ (sAmAnya rUp)** or Oblique case form.

blocks.heading: Note
blocks.content:
For "He" and This(male) etc., both forms are correct. ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ(tyAchyA), ‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ(hyAchyA) are used more frequently. ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ(tyA), ‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ(hyA) are used in formal Marathi writing.

The pronoun for "self" is ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡§É (svatH) and its ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™ is same: ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡§É (svatH).

title: Marathi Barakahadi : Symbols for vowels with consonants
content: Marathi Barakhadi: how vowels combine with consonants.
intro: In the previous lesson, we have studied symbols in the Devanagari script for consonants and vowels. Now let's learn the next concept of Marathi Barakhadi. Like in any language, vowels can be added to consonants to create combined sound. There are twelve main vowels. Hence this chart is called "bArAkhaDI"; where "bArA" means twelve.

blocks.heading: Introduction
blocks.content:
In English we just write letters one after another; and based on the word pronunciation say them together. e.g. meat; bit; hat. Here "ea", "i", "a" are pronounced along with preceding consonant.

In Marathi, we do not write vowels as it is when they are to be combined with a consonant. There are different symbols for each vowel, which is added to the consonant symbol to indicate combined sound.

blocks.heading: ‡§Ö (a) ‚Äì No change
blocks.content: Adding ‡§Ö(a) to consonant has no effect. So there is no change in symbol. In this blog, it is denoted as small a i.e. "a".

blocks.heading: ‡§Ü (A) ‚Äì Vertical line (‡§æ)
blocks.content:
Adding ‡§Ü(A) to consonant is denoted by extra vertical line (‡§æ). This vertical line is called ‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡§æ (kAnA).

‡§ï(k) + ‡§Ü(A) = ‡§ï‡§æ (kA)
‡§¨(b) + ‡§Ü(A) = ‡§¨‡§æ (bA)

In this blog, it is denoted as capital a i.e. "A".

blocks.heading: ‡§á (i) ‚Äì Before consonant (‡§ø)
blocks.content:
Adding ‡§á(i) to consonant is denoted by an extra vertical line and a curve BEFORE consonant (‡§ø). This is called ‡§™‡§π‡§ø‡§≤‡•Ä ‡§µ‡•á‡§≤‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ü‡•Ä (pahili velAMTI).

‡§ï(k) + ‡§á(i) = ‡§ï‡§ø(ki)
‡§¨(b) + ‡§á(i) = ‡§¨‡§ø(bi)

In this blog it is denoted as small i i.e. "i".

blocks.heading: ‡§à (I) ‚Äì After consonant (‡•Ä)
blocks.content:
Adding ‡§à(I) to consonant is denoted by an extra vertical line and a curve AFTER consonant (‡•Ä). This is called ‡§¶‡•Å‡§∏‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§µ‡•á‡§≤‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ü‡•Ä (dusari velAMTI).

‡§ï(k) + ‡§à(I) = ‡§ï‡•Ä(kI)
‡§¨(b) + ‡§à(I) = ‡§¨‡•Ä(bI)

In this blog it is denoted as capital i i.e. "I".

blocks.heading: ‡§â (u) ‚Äì Curve below, left (‡•Å)
blocks.content:
Adding ‡§â(u) to consonant is denoted by a curve below consonant. The curve is pointing to left (‡•Å). This curve is called ‡§™‡§π‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ ‡§â‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ (pahilA ukAr).

‡§ï(k) + ‡§â(u) = ‡§ï‡•Å(ku)
‡§¨(b) + ‡§â(u) = ‡§¨‡•Å(bu)

Exception: for ‡§∞(r) curve is added at side ‡§∞‡•Å(ru). In this blog, it is denoted as small u i.e. "u".

blocks.heading: ‡§ä (U) ‚Äì Curve below, right (‡•Ç)
blocks.content:
Adding ‡§ä(U) to consonant is denoted by a curve below consonant. The curve is pointing to the right (‡•Ç). This curve is called ‡§¶‡•Å‡§∏‡§∞‡§æ ‡§â‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ (dusarA ukAr).

‡§ï(k) + ‡§ä(U) = ‡§ï‡•Ç(kU)
‡§¨(b) + ‡§ä(U) = ‡§¨‡•Ç(bU)

Exception: for ‡§∞(r) curve is added at side ‡§∞‡•Ç(rU). In this blog, it is denoted as capital u i.e. "U".

blocks.heading: ‡§è (e) ‚Äì Slanting line above (‡•á)
blocks.content:
Adding ‡§è(e) to consonant is denoted by a slanting line above consonant (‡•á). This slanting line is called ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ (mAtrA).

‡§ï(k) + ‡§è(e) = ‡§ï‡•á(ke)
‡§¨(b) + ‡§è(e) = ‡§¨‡•á(be)

In this blog it is denoted as small e i.e. "e".

blocks.heading: ‡§ê (ai) ‚Äì Two slanting lines (‡•à)
blocks.content:
Adding ‡§ê(ai) to consonant is denoted by TWO slanting lines above consonant (‡•à). These slanting lines are called ‡§¶‡•ã‡§® ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ (don mAtrA). Where ‡§¶‡•ã‡§® (don) means two.

‡§ï(k) + ‡§ê(ai) = ‡§ï‡•à(kai)
‡§¨(b) + ‡§ê(ai) = ‡§¨‡•à(bai)

In this blog, it is denoted as "ai". Note for native Hindi speakers: read the section "Difference in pronunciation of double Matra in Marathi and Hindi" at the end of this lesson.

blocks.heading: ‡§ì (o) ‚Äì Vertical line + one slant (‡•ã)
blocks.content:
Adding ‡§ì(o) to consonant is denoted by a vertical line after consonant along with one slanting line above consonant (‡•ã). i.e. one ‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡§æ (kAnA) and one ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ (mAtrA).

‡§ï(k) + ‡§ì(o) = ‡§ï‡•ã(ko)
‡§¨(b) + ‡§ì(o) = ‡§¨‡•ã(bo)

In this blog, it is denoted as small o i.e. "o".

blocks.heading: ‡§î (au) ‚Äì Vertical line + two slants (‡•å)
blocks.content:
Adding ‡§î(au) to consonant is denoted by a vertical line after consonant along with TWO slanting lines above consonant (‡•å). i.e. one ‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡§æ (kAnA) and two ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ (mAtrA).

‡§ï(k) + ‡§î(au) = ‡§ï‡•å(kau)
‡§¨(b) + ‡§î(au) = ‡§¨‡•å(bau)

In this blog it is denoted as "au". Note for native Hindi speakers: read the section "Difference in pronunciation of double Matra in Marathi and Hindi" at the end of this blog.

blocks.heading: ‡§Ö‡§Ç (aM) ‚Äì Dot on consonant (‡§Ç)
blocks.content:
Adding ‡§Ö‡§Ç(aM) to consonant is denoted by a dot on the consonant (‡§Ç).

‡§ï(k) + ‡§Ö‡§Ç(aM) = ‡§ï‡§Ç(kM)
‡§¨(b) + ‡§Ö‡§Ç(aM) = ‡§¨‡§Ç(bM)

In this blog, it is denoted as capital m "M". For more details on the pronunciation of anusvar refer: http://kaushiklele-learnmarathi.blogspot.com/2012/05/pronunciation-of-anusvar.html

blocks.heading: ‡§Ö‡§É (aH) ‚Äì Two dots after (‡§É)
blocks.content:
Adding ‡§Ö‡§É(aH) to consonant is denoted by two dots after a consonant (‡§É).

‡§ï(k) + ‡§Ö‡§É(aH) = ‡§ï‡§É(kH)
‡§¨(b) + ‡§Ö‡§É(aH) = ‡§¨‡§É(bH)

In this blog, it is denoted as capital h i.e. "H".

blocks.heading: ‡§Ö‡•Ö (~a) ‚Äì Crescent above (‡•Ö)
blocks.content:
Adding ‡§Ö‡•Ö(~a) to consonant is denoted by giving a crescent above consonant (‡•Ö).

‡§ï(k) + ‡§Ö‡•Ö(~a) = ‡§ï‡•Ö(k~a)
‡§¨(b) + ‡§Ö‡•Ö(~a) = ‡§¨‡•Ö(b~a)

In this blog, it is denoted as "~a".

blocks.heading: ‡§ë (~o) ‚Äì Crescent + vertical line (‡•â)
blocks.content:
Adding ‡§ë(~o) to consonant is denoted by giving a crescent above consonant along with vertical line after a consonant (‡•â).

‡§ï(k) + ‡§ë(~o) = ‡§ï‡•â(k~o)
‡§¨(b) + ‡§ë(~o) = ‡§¨‡•â(b~o)

In this blog, it is denoted as "~o".

blocks.heading: Half consonant (‡•ç)
blocks.content:
When you want to say a consonant just half, it is denoted by giving a slanting line below the consonant (‡•ç).

‡§ï‡•ç  ‡§¨‡•ç

title: Phrase "To Make Someone do something"
content:
In English, we use sentences like ‚ÄúI will make him work‚Äù, ‚ÄúThat joke made him laugh‚Äù etc.
So we use the phrase here as ‚Äúto make one do something‚Äù.
In Marathi we say it ‡§Æ‡•Ä ‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§≤‡§æ ‡§≤‡§æ‡§µ‡•Ä‡§® ( mI karAyalA lAvIn ), ‡§Æ‡•Ä ‡§¨‡•ã‡§≤‡§æ‡§Ø‡§≤‡§æ ‡§≤‡§æ‡§µ‡•Ä‡§®( mI bolAyalA lAvIn ).
Sentence structure is:
Subject i.e. ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§æ (kartA )
Object or noun with preposition ‚ÄúTo‚Äù
Verb+‡§Ü‡§Ø‡§≤‡§æ (AyalA)
Verb form of  ‡§≤‡§æ‡§µ‡§£‡•á (lAvaNe) as per tense
‡§Æ‡•Ä (mI)

‡§¨‡•ã‡§≤‡§æ‡§Ø‡§≤‡§æ(bolAyalA)
‡§≤‡§æ‡§µ‡•Ä‡§®(lAvIn)
Needless to say, Form of ‡§≤‡§æ‡§µ‡§£‡•á (lAvaNe) follows the general rules of sentence formation. i.e.
For

title: Practise Marathi online ! Let's talk on Skype or Hangout
content:
On the occasion of Maharashtra Day (1st May 2018), I am introducing a new facility for Marathi learners. I would like to interact with them on web-chats, practice conversation, answer their queries. The timings can be decided based on mutual convenience. It is free of cost.
Share with your friends, relatives, colleagues who want to Learn Marathi !!
I conduct a separate session for non-Indian students. They have been really global sessions with participants from the US to Japan joining them. It is online, once a week on Google hangout (group video chat). It is not a sequential teaching session. But more of QnA and conversation practice. Everyone is at a different and basic stage of learning. It is held Saturday/Sunday India evening time. Let me know if you are interested to join.

title: Preposition "TO" in Marathi
content: Preposition "TO" in Marathi
intro: Preposition "To" is ‡§≤‡§æ (lA) in Marathi. Special forms incorporate ‡§≤‡§æ, so no need to add it again.

blocks.heading: Introduction
blocks.content:
The preposition "To" in English is ‡§≤‡§æ (lA) in Marathi. But "To" is handled differently: special forms are created incorporating ‡§≤‡§æ. So no need to add ‡§≤‡§æ again.

e.g. "to him" in English is ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ (tyAlA) in Marathi. The form already has ‡§≤‡§æ in it.

Give it to him -> ‡§π‡•á ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ ‡§¶‡•á (he tyAlA de)

blocks.heading: Self
blocks.content: For "self" (‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡§É): form with "To" is ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡§É‡§≤‡§æ (svatHlA).

blocks.heading: Old style Marathi using ‡§∏(sa)
blocks.content:
In old/formal Marathi, prefix ‡§∏(sa) is used instead of ‡§≤‡§æ(lA) for third person:
- To him/it: ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ = ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏ (tyAs)
- To her: ‡§§‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ = ‡§§‡•Ä‡§∏ (tIs)
- To them: ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç‡§®‡§æ = ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏ (tyAMs)
- To you (very formal): ‡§Ü‡§™‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ = ‡§Ü‡§™‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏ (ApanAs)

Examples: ‡§ß‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§∞‡§™‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§∏ ‡§Æ‡§®‡§æ‡§à ‡§Ü‡§π‡•á (prohibition to smoking); ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ ‡§™‡§æ‡§π‡•Å‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏ ‡§≠‡•á‡§ü‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Ç ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§≥‡•á‡§≤ (gift to all guests).

For first/second person (rarely used): To me = ‡§Æ‡§ú (maja), To you = ‡§§‡•Å‡§ú (tuja).

title: Prepositions with similar pronunciation or similar meanings
content: Prepositions with similar pronunciation or similar meanings
intro: Advanced topic. Some prepositions sound similar but have different meanings. Early learners can skip.

blocks.heading: 1: ‡§Æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á (madhye) & ‡§Æ‡§ß‡•Ç‡§® (madhUn)
blocks.content:
**‡§Æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á** (madhye) = inside. **‡§Æ‡§ß‡•Ç‡§®** (madhUn) = from inside.

Keep tea-spoon inside drawer, take table-spoon from drawer -> ‡§ü‡§ø-‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡•Ç‡§® ‡§°‡•ç‡§∞‡•â‡§µ‡§∞ ‡§Æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§†‡•á‡§µ ‡§Ü‡§£‡§ø ‡§ü‡•á‡§¨‡§≤ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡•Ç‡§® ‡§°‡•ç‡§∞‡•â‡§µ‡§∞ ‡§Æ‡§ß‡•Ç‡§® ‡§¨‡§æ‡§π‡•á‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§¢ (Ti-spUn drawer madhye Thev ANi Tebal spUn drawer madhUn bAher kADh).

**‡§Æ‡§ß‡§≤‡§æ** (madhalA) = adjective (middle/one within). Middle stump -> ‡§Æ‡§ß‡§≤‡§æ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§ü‡§Ç‡§™ (madhalA sTaMp).

blocks.heading: 2: ‡§ï‡§°‡•á (kaDe) & ‡§ï‡§°‡•Ç‡§® (kaDUn)
blocks.content:
**‡§ï‡§°‡•á** (kaDe) = to/towards. **‡§ï‡§°‡•Ç‡§®** (kaDUn) = from. ‡§ï‡§°‡•Ç‡§® = source/direction; ‡§ï‡§°‡•á = destination.

Throne passed from king to prince -> ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Ç‡§®‡§Ç‡§§‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§ø‡§Ç‡§π‡§æ‡§∏‡§® ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ‡§ï‡§°‡•Ç‡§® ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡§°‡•á ‡§ó‡•á‡§≤‡•á (rAjAchyA mRutyUnaMtar siMhAsan rAjAkaDUn rAjaputrAkaDe gele).
Sun travels from east towards west -> ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§ï‡§°‡•Ç‡§® ‡§™‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§Æ‡•á‡§ï‡§°‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§§‡•ã (sUrya pUrvekaDUn paSchimekaDe pravAs karato).

blocks.heading: 3: ‡§™‡§æ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§® (pAsUn) & ‡§ï‡§°‡•Ç‡§® (kaDUn)
blocks.content:
Both mean "from". **‡§™‡§æ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§®** (pAsUn) = starting point (use with ‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç‡§§). **‡§ï‡§°‡•Ç‡§®** (kaDUn) = direction of movement (use with ‡§ï‡§°‡•á).

Distance Mumbai to Pune -> ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§Ç‡§¨‡§à‡§™‡§æ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§® ‡§™‡•Å‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç‡§§‡§ö‡•á ‡§Ö‡§Ç‡§§‡§∞ 149 KM ‡§Ü‡§π‡•á (muMbaIpAsUn puNyAparyaMtache aMtar 149 KM Ahe).
From his place to my place -> ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ï‡§°‡•Ç‡§® ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ù‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ï‡§°‡•á ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§≤‡§æ ‡§§‡•Ä‡§® ‡§§‡§æ‡§∏ ‡§≤‡§æ‡§ó‡§§‡§æ‡§§ (tyAchyAkaDUn mAjhyAkaDe yAyalA tIn tAs lAgatAt).

For time: always ‡§™‡§æ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§®-‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç‡§§ (pAsUn-paryaMt). ‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§™‡§æ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§® ‡§Ü‡§ú‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç‡§§ (kAlapAsUn AjaparyaMt). Never ‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§ï‡§°‡•Ç‡§® (kAlakaDUn).

blocks.heading: 4: ‡§π‡•Ç‡§®, ‡§§‡•Ç‡§®, ‡§µ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§®, ‡§ï‡§°‡•Ç‡§®
blocks.content:
**‡§π‡•Ç‡§®** (hUn): from a place (city, village). He came from London -> ‡§§‡•ã ‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤ ‡§≤‡§Ç‡§°‡§®‡§π‡•Ç‡§® ‡§Ü‡§≤‡§æ (to kAl laMDanahUn AlA).

**‡§§‡•Ç‡§®** (tUn): from inside. Similar to ‡§Æ‡§ß‡•Ç‡§®. From village -> ‡§ó‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•Ç‡§®/‡§ó‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ß‡•Ç‡§® (gAvAtUn/gAvAmadhUn).

**‡§µ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§®** (varUn): via. Train via your city -> ‡§§‡•Å‡§ù‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∂‡§π‡§∞‡§æ‡§µ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§® ‡§ú‡§æ‡§à‡§≤ (tujhyA shaharAvarUn jAIl). What did you bring from (via) Delhi? -> ‡§¶‡§ø‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡•Ä‡§µ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§® ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§Ü‡§£‡§≤‡•á‡§∏? (dillIvarUn kAy ANales?)

**‡§ï‡§°‡•Ç‡§®** (kaDUn): other cases. I did not get help from him -> ‡§Æ‡§≤‡§æ ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ï‡§°‡•Ç‡§® ‡§ï‡§æ‡§π‡•Ä ‡§Æ‡§¶‡§§ ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§≥‡§æ‡§≤‡•Ä ‡§®‡§æ‡§π‡•Ä (malA tyAchyAkaDUn kAhI madat miLAlI nAhI).

blocks.heading: 5: ‡§≤‡§æ (lA) & other cases
blocks.content: **‡§≤‡§æ** (lA) = destination. To office -> ‡§ë‡§´‡§ø‡§∏‡§≤‡§æ (ophisalA). To school -> ‡§∂‡§æ‡§≥‡•á‡§≤‡§æ (shALelA) or ‡§∂‡§æ‡§≥‡•á‡§§ (shALet). To home -> ‡§ò‡§∞‡•Ä (gharI) only (not ‡§ò‡§∞‡§≤‡§æ in standard Marathi).

blocks.heading: 6: ‡§Æ‡§ß‡•á, ‡§Æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á, ‡§§
blocks.content:
All mean in/among. Interchangeable. Append to ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™ (sAmAnya rUp).

Pot (‡§Æ‡§æ‡§† mATh) -> ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§†‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ß‡•á/‡§Æ‡§æ‡§†‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á/‡§Æ‡§æ‡§†‡§æ‡§§ (mAThAmadhe/mAThAmadhye/mAThAt). Jar (‡§¨‡§∞‡§£‡•Ä baraNI) -> ‡§¨‡§∞‡§£‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§ß‡•á/‡§¨‡§∞‡§£‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á/‡§¨‡§∞‡§£‡•Ä‡§§ (baraNImadhe/baraNImadhye/baraNIt). Leaf (‡§™‡§æ‡§® pAn) -> ‡§™‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ß‡•á/‡§™‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á/‡§™‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§§ (pAnAmadhe/pAnAmadhye/pAnAt).

For English words: prefer ‡§Æ‡§ß‡•á/‡§Æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á (madhe/madhye). ‡§§ (t) with ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™ can sound odd for English words.

title: Prepositions with verbs in Marathi
content:
In Hindi, we use ‡§Ö‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø (avyay) i.e. prepositions with verb e.g. ‡§¨‡•ã‡§≤‡§®‡•á ‡§ï‡•á ‡§¨‡§æ‡§¶ ( bolane ke bAd ), ‡§¨‡•ã‡§≤‡§®‡•á ‡§ï‡•á ‡§≤‡§ø‡§Ø‡•á (bolane ke liye), ‡§¨‡•ã‡§≤‡§§‡•á ‡§¨‡•ã‡§≤‡§§‡•á ( bolate bolate), ‡§¨‡•ã‡§≤‡§®‡•á ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ( bolane meM ) etc.
As you can observe, in Hindi prepositions viz. ‡§¨‡§æ‡§¶, ‡§≤‡§ø‡§Ø‡•á, ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç etc. are added to ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™ (sAmAnya rUp) of verb viz. ‚Äú‡§¨‡•ã‡§≤‡§®‡•á‚Äù
In Marathi also, ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™ (sAmAnya rUp) of the verb is used to append preposition.
In Marathi generally, ‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ (NyA) is suffixed to verb before adding ‡§Ö‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø ( avyay).
e.g.
Verb in Hindi

title: Prepositions with Verbs
content:
We have seen that when using a preposition with pronouns or nouns, the form of pronouns or nouns changes which is called ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™ (sAmAnya rUp) in Marathi or Oblique case form in English. The same way happens while using a preposition with the verb.

In English we use the ‚Äú-ing‚Äù form of the verb for proposition usage.
In Marathi ‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ (NyA) is suffixed to verb.

title: Present Continuous Tense in Marathi
content: Present Continuous Tense in Marathi
intro: Learn how to form Present Continuous tense: Pronoun + verb (Simple Present form) + form of ‡§Ö‡§∏‡§£‡•á.

blocks.heading: Structure
blocks.content:
After learning Simple Present Tense of "To be" in Marathi, it is easy to march toward learning Present Continuous tense (PCT) in Marathi.

In English PCT sentence is formed as: Pronoun + form of To be + Verb+-ing (e.g. I am doing)

In Marathi PCT sentence is formed as: Pronoun + form of verb in Simple Present Tense + form of ‡§Ö‡§∏‡§£‡•á (asaNe)

Example: I -> ‡§Æ‡•Ä, Do -> ‡§ï‡§∞, Am -> ‡§Ü‡§π‡•á. So ‡§Æ‡•Ä ‡§ï‡§∞‡§§‡•ã ‡§Ü‡§π‡•á (mI karato Ahe) = I am doing.

Another example: "He eats" is ‡§§‡•ã ‡§ñ‡§æ‡§§‡•ã. Form of ‡§Ö‡§∏‡§£‡•á for He is ‡§Ü‡§π‡•á. So ‡§§‡•ã ‡§ñ‡§æ‡§§‡•ã ‡§Ü‡§π‡•á = He is eating.

Similarly: ‡§§‡•Ä ‡§∞‡§°‡§§‡•á -> ‡§§‡•Ä ‡§∞‡§°‡§§‡•á ‡§Ü‡§π‡•á (tI raDate Ahe) = She is crying.

blocks.heading: Exceptions
blocks.content:
**1) Exception for "You":** You (male) eat -> ‡§§‡•Ç ‡§ñ‡§æ‡§§‡•ã‡§∏ (tU khAtos). Form of ‡§Ö‡§∏‡§£‡•á for You is ‡§Ü‡§π‡•á‡§∏ (Ahes). So Present continuous would be "‡§§‡•Ç ‡§ñ‡§æ‡§§‡•ã‡§∏ ‡§Ü‡§π‡•á‡§∏". But the ending ‡§∏(s) is NOT used in the verb. The sentence is: **‡§§‡•Ç ‡§ñ‡§æ‡§§‡•ã ‡§Ü‡§π‡•á‡§∏**.

**2) Exception for "They":** They eat -> ‡§§‡•á/‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ/‡§§‡•Ä ‡§ñ‡§æ‡§§‡§æ‡§§ (te/tyA/tI khAtAt). Form of ‡§Ö‡§∏‡§£‡•á for They is ‡§Ü‡§π‡•á‡§§ (Ahet). So it would be "‡§§‡•á/‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ/‡§§‡•Ä ‡§ñ‡§æ‡§§‡§æ‡§§ ‡§Ü‡§π‡•á‡§§". But the ending ‡§§‡§æ‡§§ (tAt) is NOT used. Instead only ‡§§(t) is used. The sentence is: **‡§§‡•á/‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ/‡§§‡•Ä ‡§ñ‡§æ‡§§ ‡§Ü‡§π‡•á‡§§**.

blocks.heading: Suffix chart for Present Continuous (exceptions highlighted)
Style 2 of Present Continuous
blocks.content:
Second style is the same as above. The only difference is that for all nouns and pronouns the suffix for the verb is ‡§§(t). Both styles are correct and part of standard Marathi.

**Examples:**
- I (male) am doing: Style 1 ‡§Æ‡•Ä ‡§ï‡§∞‡§§‡•ã ‡§Ü‡§π‡•á | Style 2 ‡§Æ‡•Ä ‡§ï‡§∞‡§§ ‡§Ü‡§π‡•á
- She is speaking: Style 1 ‡§§‡•Ä ‡§¨‡•ã‡§≤‡§§‡•á ‡§Ü‡§π‡•á | Style 2 ‡§§‡•Ä ‡§¨‡•ã‡§≤‡§§ ‡§Ü‡§π‡•á
- It is moving: Style 1 ‡§§‡•á ‡§π‡§≤‡§§‡•á ‡§Ü‡§π‡•á | Style 2 ‡§§‡•á ‡§π‡§≤‡§§ ‡§Ü‡§π‡•á
- You (male) are crying: Style 1 ‡§§‡•Ç ‡§∞‡§°‡§§‡•ã ‡§Ü‡§π‡•á‡§∏ | Style 2 ‡§§‡•Ç ‡§∞‡§°‡§§ ‡§Ü‡§π‡•á‡§∏

Learning these rules will help you study the rules for other continuous tenses.

title: Present/Past/Future Perfect Tense in Marathi
content: Present/Past/Future Perfect Tense in Marathi
intro: Perfect tenses = Simple past sentence + form of ‡§Ö‡§∏‡§£‡•á. If verb has object, use form as per object; otherwise as per subject.

blocks.heading: Rule 1: Verbs with noun/object
blocks.content:
**Logic:** Simple past sentence + form of ‡§Ö‡§∏‡§£‡•á as per gender/multiplicity of **noun** and tense.

**Example:** "I have/had/will have opened box"
- Simple past: ‡§Æ‡•Ä ‡§ñ‡•ã‡§ï‡§æ ‡§â‡§ò‡§°‡§≤‡§æ (mI khokA ughaDalA). Object = Box (masculine).
- Past perfect: + ‡§π‡•ã‡§§‡§æ -> ‡§Æ‡•Ä ‡§ñ‡•ã‡§ï‡§æ ‡§â‡§ò‡§°‡§≤‡§æ ‡§π‡•ã‡§§‡§æ
- Present perfect: + ‡§Ü‡§π‡•á -> ‡§Æ‡•Ä ‡§ñ‡•ã‡§ï‡§æ ‡§â‡§ò‡§°‡§≤‡§æ ‡§Ü‡§π‡•á
- Future perfect: + ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•á‡§≤ -> ‡§Æ‡•Ä ‡§ñ‡•ã‡§ï‡§æ ‡§â‡§ò‡§°‡§≤‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•á‡§≤

blocks.heading: Rule 2: Verbs without noun/object
blocks.content:
**Logic:** Simple past sentence + form of ‡§Ö‡§∏‡§£‡•á as per gender/multiplicity of **Subject** and tense.

**Example:** "I(male) have/had/will have spoken"
- Simple past: ‡§Æ‡•Ä ‡§¨‡•ã‡§≤‡§≤‡•ã (mI bolalo). Subject = I(male).
- Past perfect: + ‡§π‡•ã‡§§‡•ã -> ‡§Æ‡•Ä ‡§¨‡•ã‡§≤‡§≤‡•ã ‡§π‡•ã‡§§‡•ã
- Present perfect: + ‡§Ü‡§π‡•á -> ‡§Æ‡•Ä ‡§¨‡•ã‡§≤‡§≤‡•ã ‡§Ü‡§π‡•á
- Future perfect: + ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•á‡§® -> ‡§Æ‡•Ä ‡§¨‡•ã‡§≤‡§≤‡•ã ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•á‡§®

blocks.heading: Forms of ‡§Ö‡§∏‡§£‡•á for all three tenses
Example 1: She has/had/will have opened door
blocks.content: Simple past: ‡§§‡•Ä‡§®‡•á ‡§¶‡§∞‡§µ‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ ‡§â‡§ò‡§°‡§≤‡§æ (tIne daravAjA ughaDalA). Object = door (masculine). Append form of ‡§Ö‡§∏‡§£‡•á for He.

blocks.heading: Example 2: You(female) have/had/will have danced
blocks.content: Simple past: ‡§§‡•Ç ‡§®‡§æ‡§ö‡§≤‡•Ä‡§∏ (tU nAchalIs). Verb has no object, so use form as per subject. Omit ‡§∏ from ‡§®‡§æ‡§ö‡§≤‡•Ä‡§∏ for Perfect.

blocks.heading: Example 3: You(plural) have/had/will have danced
blocks.content: Simple past: ‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡•Ä ‡§®‡§æ‡§ö‡§≤‡§æ‡§§ (tumhI nAchalAt). Omit ‡§§ from ‡§®‡§æ‡§ö‡§≤‡§æ‡§§ for Perfect.

blocks.heading: Note
blocks.content: For ‡§§‡•Ç and ‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡•Ä, omit ending ‡§∏(s) and ‡§§(t) of simple past when making Perfect tense.

title: Pronouns and Articles in Marathi
content: Pronouns and Articles in Marathi
intro: Learn Marathi pronouns and the difference from English articles. Use the speaker buttons to hear pronunciation.

blocks.heading: Introduction
blocks.content:
Let us learn Marathi's pronouns today. The below chart has the list.

As I would always say, go through the list once. But do not get daunted by the details. When we will start preparing sentences, come back to the chart and get the required pronoun. Using them frequently will make you familiar. And afterward, you will not need to come back to this chart.

blocks.heading: Difference between ‡§Ü‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡•Ä (AmhI) and ‡§Ü‡§™‡§£ (ApaN)
blocks.content: **‡§Ü‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡•Ä (AmhI)** is used when the listener is not included. **‡§Ü‡§™‡§£ (ApaN)** is used when the listener is included.

blocks.heading: ‡§Ü‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡•Ä vs ‡§Ü‡§™‡§£ ‚Äì Examples
rows: We went to the party (listener not included)
We went to the party (listener included)

blocks.heading: Learn Articles in Marathi and English
blocks.content: In English there are three articles: "a", "an", and "the". In Marathi there is no custom of using such articles.

title: Pronunciation of Anusvar ‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞
content: Pronunciation of Anusvar ‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞
intro: The dot (‡§Ç) on a character is called ‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞ (anusvAr). Its pronunciation depends on the character that follows it. Use the speaker buttons to hear examples.

blocks.heading: Explanation for ‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞ (anusvAr)
blocks.content:
In the table for vowels there is row:

‡§Ö‡§Ç  aM  ‚Äî As sound of "um" in number, sound of "um" as in jump

This will need more attention to understand its pronunciation. The dot given on the character is called **‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞** (anusvAr).

The anusvaar (‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞) is a nasal sound. The ‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞ itself does not determine the pronunciation of a word. Rather, it is the character that **follows** the ‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞ that determines the pronunciation. There are several possibilities that affect the pronunciation of ‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞.

So though we will use capital 'M' to indicate ‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞, you may need to pronounce it differently depending on the case.

blocks.heading: Rule 1: Followed by ‡§ï, ‡§ñ, ‡§ó, ‡§ò
blocks.content: If the nasal dot is followed by ‡§ï (k), ‡§ñ (kh), ‡§ó (g), ‡§ò (gh), the nasal dot is pronounced as ‡§ô (·πÖ) ‚Äî e.g. 'n' in "sing".

blocks.heading: Rule 2: Followed by ‡§ö, ‡§õ, ‡§ú, ‡§ù
blocks.content: If the nasal dot is followed by ‡§ö (ch), ‡§õ (Ch), ‡§ú (j), ‡§ù (jh), the dot is pronounced as ‡§û (√±) ‚Äî e.g. 'n' in the English word "munch".

blocks.heading: Rule 3: Followed by ‡§ü, ‡§†, ‡§°, ‡§¢, ‡§£
blocks.content: If the nasal dot is followed by ‡§ü (T), ‡§† (Th), ‡§° (D), ‡§¢ (Dh), ‡§£ (N), the dot is pronounced as ‡§£ (N).

blocks.heading: Rule 4: Followed by ‡§§, ‡§•, ‡§¶, ‡§ß, ‡§®
blocks.content: If the nasal dot is followed by ‡§§ (t), ‡§• (th), ‡§¶ (d), ‡§ß (dh), ‡§® (n), the dot is pronounced as ‡§® (n).

blocks.heading: Rule 5: Followed by ‡§™, ‡§´, ‡§¨, ‡§≠, ‡§Æ
blocks.content: If the nasal dot is followed by ‡§™ (p), ‡§´ (ph), ‡§¨ (b), ‡§≠ (bh), ‡§Æ (m), the dot is pronounced as ‡§Æ (m).

blocks.heading: Rule 6: Followed by ‡§Ø, ‡§∞, ‡§≤, ‡§µ, ‡§∂, ‡§∑, ‡§∏, ‡§π, ‡§≥, ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑, ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û
blocks.content: If the nasal dot is followed by ‡§Ø (y), ‡§∞ (r), ‡§≤ (l), ‡§µ (v), ‡§∂ (sh), ‡§∑ (Sh), ‡§∏ (s), ‡§π (h), ‡§≥ (L), ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑ (kSh), ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û (dny), the dot is pronounced as ‡§Ö‡§Ç (aM).

blocks.heading: Rule 7: Followed by space
blocks.content:
If the nasal dot is followed by the space character, the dot is pronounced as half ‡§Æ (m).

Example: ‡§è‡§µ‡§Ç = ‡§è‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç (evam)

blocks.heading: Rule 8: Colloquial change in pronunciation
blocks.content:
In day-to-day communication, words ending with vowel ‡§è (e) are said a little differently. Instead of pronouncing ‡§è (e), the consonant is pronounced elongated. This change is indicated by ‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞; though there is no nasal sound. (To know more, refer **Short forms in spoken Marathi**)

E.g. "Trees" in English is ‡§ù‡§æ‡§°‡•á (jhADe) in Marathi. But in day-to-day communication, it can be said as ‡§ù‡§æ‡§°‡§Ç (jhADM), where ending ‡§° (d) is pronounced elongated. Similarly "Leaves" is ‡§™‡§æ‡§®‡•á (pAne). It can also be said as ‡§™‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç (pAnM).

**Rule of thumb for combined words:**
- If the word ends with ‡§§‡§∞ (tar), ‡§§‡§∞‡•Ä (tarI), ‡§π‡•Ä (hI) then it is a combined word. e.g. ‡§ï‡§∏‡§Ç‡§§‡§∞‡•Ä (kasaMtarI), ‡§ï‡•Å‡§†‡§Ç‡§π‡•Ä (kuThMhI), ‡§ñ‡§∞‡§Ç‡§§‡§∞ (kharaMtar)
- If the word is a pair of two rhyming words, it is a combined word. e.g. ‡§ù‡§æ‡§°‡§Ç-‡§¨‡§ø‡§°‡§Ç (jhADMbiDM), ‡§π‡§≤‡§ï‡§Ç-‡§´‡•Å‡§≤‡§ï‡§Ç (halakaMphulakaM), ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡§Ç-‡§¨‡§ø‡§ß‡§Ç (sAdhaMbidhaM)
- If a word is a pair of opposite words, it is a combined word. e.g. ‡§ñ‡§∞‡§Ç-‡§ñ‡•ã‡§ü‡§Ç (kharaM-khoTM), ‡§≠‡§≤‡§Ç-‡§¨‡•Å‡§∞‡§Ç (bhalM-buraM)

So you should know if it is a combined word or a single word to pronounce it correctly.

blocks.heading: Rule 9: ‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞ in ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™ form of plural
blocks.content:
In ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™ form of plural of noun, whenever there is ‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞ at end, it is pronounced as light half ‡§® (n) irrespective of the following consonant.

**Example:** Word ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§™ (saMp) ‚Üí ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™ plural: ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§™‡§æ‡§Ç (saMpAM)
Full word: ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§™‡§æ‡§Ç‡§™‡§æ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§® (saMpAMpAsUn) is pronounced as ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§™‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§™‡§æ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§® (sampAnpAsUn).

Here the first ‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞ (in ‡§∏‡§Ç) is pronounced as half ‡§Æ (m) because next consonant is ‡§™ (p) ‚Äî Rule 5. But the second ‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞ (in ‡§™‡§æ‡§Ç) is pronounced as half ‡§® (n) even if next consonant is again ‡§™ (p) ‚Äî Rule 9.

title: Requesting-someone-"May-I","Can-you" etc.
content:
In English we take permission by asking ‚ÄúMay I come in‚Äù , ‚ÄúMay I use this‚Äù?
In Marathi we ask such questions as this format:-
subject ( ‡§Æ‡•Ä/‡§Ü‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡•Ä )¬† ¬† ¬†verb+‡§ä¬† ¬† ¬† ¬†‡§ï‡§æ?
e.g.
For verb ‚ÄúTo come‚Äù i.e. ‚Äú‡§Ø‡•á‚Äù(ye) -> ‡§Æ‡•Ä ‡§Ø‡•á‡§ä ‡§ï‡§æ ? (mI yeU kA)
For verb ‚ÄúTo go‚Äù i.e. ‚Äú‡§ú‡§æ ‚Äú(jA) -> ‡§Æ‡•Ä ‡§ú‡§æ‡§ä ‡§ï‡§æ ? ( mI jAU kA )
Examples:-
May I come -> ‡§Æ‡•Ä ‡§Ø‡•á‡§ä ‡§ï‡§æ? (mI yeU kA)
May I go -> ‡§Æ‡•Ä ‡§ú‡§æ‡§ä ‡§ï‡§æ? (mI jAU kA)
May we come -> ‡§Ü‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡•Ä ‡§Ø‡•á‡§ä ‡§ï‡§æ? (AmhI yeU kA)
May we go -> ‡§Ü‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡•Ä ‡§ú‡§æ‡§ä ‡§ï‡§æ? (AmhI jAU kA)
May we speak -> ‡§Ü‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡•Ä ‡§¨‡•ã‡§≤‡•Ç ‡§ï‡§æ ( AmhI bolU kA )
In English, we request others as ‚ÄúMay you come‚Äù , ‚ÄúMay you say‚Äù.
The same sentences can be said as ‚ÄúCan you come‚Äù, ‚ÄúCan you say‚Äù.
In Marathi there is not separate from ‚ÄúMay you‚Äù, ‚ÄúMay he‚Äù etc. So when using ‚ÄúMay‚Äù with other than ‚ÄúI‚Äù or ‚ÄúWe‚Äù, sentences should be said as ‚ÄúCan you‚Äù, ‚ÄúCan he‚Äù etc.
Refer this lesson to know more details using ‚ÄúCan‚Äù in Marathi :
Using the verb ‚ÄúCan/To be able to‚Äù
Examples:-
May you come -> Can you come -> ‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡•Ä ‡§Ø‡•á‡§ä ‡§∂‡§ï‡§§‡§æ ‡§ï‡§æ? ( tumhI yeU shakatA kA ? )
May you speak -> Can you speak -> ‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡•Ä ‡§¨‡•ã‡§≤‡•Ç ‡§∂‡§ï‡§§‡§æ ‡§ï‡§æ? ( tumhI bolU shakatA kA )
May he tell -> Can he tell -> ‡§§‡•ã ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ó‡•Ç ‡§∂‡§ï‡§§‡•ã ‡§ï‡§æ? ( to sAMgU shakato kA ? )
Can I tell -> ‡§Æ‡•Ä ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ó‡•Ç ‡§∂‡§ï‡§§‡•ã ‡§ï‡§æ? ( mI sAMgU shakato kA ? )
Can I write -> ‡§Æ‡•Ä ‡§≤‡§ø‡§π‡•Ç ‡§∂‡§ï‡§§‡•ã ‡§ï‡§æ? ( mI lihU shakato kA ? )
Sometimes Marathi people request this way as well ‚Äú‡§™‡•á‡§® ‡§¶‡•á‡§§‡§æ ‡§ï‡§æ‚Äù ( ‚Äúpen detA kA‚Äù) ,‚Äù‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ó‡§§‡§æ ‡§ï‡§æ‚Äù ( ‚ÄúpattA sAMgatA kA‚Äù ). To translate it literally it is ‚ÄúDo you give pen‚Äù, ‚ÄúDo you tell address‚Äù. It might sound weird to an English speaker. But this is the style used in Marathi. This style is used only for ‚Äúyou‚Äù ‚Äì single as well as plural.
May you come -> Do you come -> ‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡§æ ‡§ï‡§æ ( yetA kA )
May you speak -> Can you speak -> ‡§¨‡•ã‡§≤‡§§‡§æ ‡§ï‡§æ? ( bolatA kA? )
May you give pen -> Do you give pen -> ‚Äú‡§™‡•á‡§® ‡§¶‡•á‡§§‡§æ ‡§ï‡§æ‚Äù ( ‚Äúpen detA kA‚Äù)
Sometimes such sentences are started with words like ‡§ú‡§∞‡§æ(jarA), ‡§•‡•ã‡§°‡§Ç ( thoDaM) to sound it more polite.
e.g.
‡§ú‡§∞‡§æ ‡§™‡•á‡§® ‡§¶‡•á‡§§‡§æ ‡§ï‡§æ ? ( jarA pen detA kA),
‡§ú‡§∞‡§æ ‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ó‡§§‡§æ ‡§ï‡§æ ? ( jarA pattA sAMgatA kA ).

‡§â‡§∏‡•á ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§ù‡§æ ( use tattv samajhA )

title: Saying have to-‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡§æ ‡§™‡§°‡•á‡§ó‡§æ-‡§ú‡§æ‡§®‡§æ ‡§™‡§°‡•á‡§ó‡§æ-karana paDegA jAnA paDegA etc.
content:
Whenever we want to indicate that another person has to do some action, in Hindi we say, ‡§§‡•Å‡§ù‡•á ‡§ú‡§æ‡§®‡§æ ‡§™‡§°‡•á‡§ó‡§æ (tujhe jAnA paDegA),‡§â‡§∏‡•á ‡§¶‡§µ‡§æ‡§à ‡§≤‡•á‡§®‡•Ä ‡§™‡§°‡•á‡§ó‡•Ä ( use davAI lenI paDegI), ‡§∏‡§≤‡•Ä‡§Æ ‡§§‡•Å‡§ù‡•á ‡§¨‡§¶‡§≤‡§®‡§æ ‡§π‡•ã‡§ó‡§æ (salIm tujhe badalanA hogA).
In Marathi, sentences structure is similar to Hindi. And it is formed using verb ‡§≤‡§æ‡§ó‡§£‡•á (‚ÄúlAgaNe‚Äù) as follows:
Form of noun/pronoun
with preposition "To"
e.g. ‚Äúto me‚Äù,‚Äùto him‚Äù etc.
verb+ ‚Äú‡§Ü‡§Ø‡§≤‡§æ ‚Äú (AyalA) OR
Verb+ form of ‚Äú‡§Ü‡§µ‡•á"(Ave) as per object
form of ‡§≤‡§æ‡§ó‡§£‡•á
(‚ÄúlAgaNe‚Äù)
as per tense and gender & multiplicity of object

‡§≤‡§æ‡§ó‡•á‡§≤

‡§Ü-‡§à-‡§è-‡§è-‡§Ø‡§æ-‡§à (A-I-e-e-yA-I) rule
‡§Ü‡§µ‡§æ-‡§Ü‡§µ‡•Ä-‡§Ü‡§µ‡•á-‡§Ü‡§µ‡•á-‡§Ü‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ-‡§Ü‡§µ‡•Ä (AvA-AvI-Ave-Ave-AvyA-AvI)

Masculine singular ‡§ú‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ (jAvA)¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Masculine plural ‡§ú‡§æ‡§µ‡•á (jAve)

title: Saying My/His/Her in Marathi

intro: Forms change by gender of the object. Singular: ‡§ö‡§æ/‡§ö‡•Ä/‡§ö‡•á. Plural: ‡§ö‡•á/‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ/‡§ö‡•Ä. For proper nouns append to ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™.

blocks.heading: My/His/Her etc.
blocks.content:
In English "My" is gender-neutral. In Marathi, form changes by gender of the **object**.

**My:** ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ù‡§æ (mAjhA) (m.) | ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ù‡•Ä (mAjhI) (f.) | ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ù‡•á (mAjhe) (n.) | Plural: ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ù‡•á/‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ù‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ/‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ù‡•Ä (mAjhe/mAjhyA/mAjhI)
- My son -> ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ù‡§æ ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§≤‡§ó‡§æ (mAjhA mulagA)
- My daughter -> ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ù‡•Ä ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§≤‡§ó‡•Ä (mAjhI mulagI)
- My Table -> ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ù‡•á ‡§ü‡•á‡§¨‡§≤ (mAjhe Tebal)
- My sons -> ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ù‡•á ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§≤‡§ó‡•á (mAjhe mulage) | My daughters -> ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ù‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§≤‡•Ä (mAjhyA mulI) | My Tables -> ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ù‡•Ä ‡§ü‡•á‡§¨‡§≤‡•á (mAjhI Tebale)

**For proper names:** Append ‡§ö‡§æ/‡§ö‡•Ä/‡§ö‡•á (chA/chI/che) (singular) or ‡§ö‡•á/‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ/‡§ö‡•Ä (che/chyA/chI) (plural) to the noun.
- Peter's son -> ‡§™‡•Ä‡§ü‡§∞‡§ö‡§æ ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§≤‡§ó‡§æ (pITarachA mulagA) | Peter's daughter -> ‡§™‡•Ä‡§ü‡§∞‡§ö‡•Ä ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§≤‡§ó‡•Ä (pITarachI mulagI) | Peter's Table -> ‡§™‡•Ä‡§ü‡§∞‡§ö‡•á ‡§ü‡•á‡§¨‡§≤ (pITarache Tebal)

blocks.heading: Suffixes with common nouns
blocks.content:
For common nouns, append ‡§ö‡§æ/‡§ö‡•Ä/‡§ö‡•á (chA/chI/che) to **‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™** (sAmAnya rUp) of the noun.
- Cuckoo -> ‡§ï‡•ã‡§ï‡§ø‡§≥‡§æ (kokiLA). ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™ ‡§ï‡•ã‡§ï‡§ø‡§≥‡•á (kokiLe). Cuckoo's voice -> ‡§ï‡•ã‡§ï‡§ø‡§≥‡•á‡§ö‡§æ ‡§Ü‡§µ‡§æ‡§ú (kokiLechA AvAj)
- Name -> ‡§®‡§æ‡§µ (nAv). ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™ ‡§®‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ (nAvA). Spelling of name -> ‡§®‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡•á ‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡•á‡§≤‡§ø‡§Ç‡§ó (nAvAche speliMg)
- Egg -> ‡§Ö‡§Ç‡§°‡•á (aMDe). Price of egg -> ‡§Ö‡§Ç‡§°‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ö‡•Ä ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç‡§Æ‡§§ (aMDyAchI kiMmat)

blocks.heading: Relating multiple words
blocks.content:
In a chain, use ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™ (sAmAnya rUp) for every word. Pronoun ‡§§‡•ã/‡§§‡•Ä/‡§§‡•á (to/tI/te) -> ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ (tyA). Suffix ‡§ö‡§æ/‡§ö‡•Ä/‡§ö‡•á (chA/chI/che) -> ‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ (chyA).

Example: Voice of that cuckoo -> ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ï‡•ã‡§ï‡§ø‡§≥‡•á‡§ö‡§æ ‡§Ü‡§µ‡§æ‡§ú (tyA kokiLechA AvAj)
Beauty of voice of that cuckoo -> ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ï‡•ã‡§ï‡§ø‡§≥‡•á‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§Ü‡§µ‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ‡§ö‡•á ‡§∏‡•å‡§Ç‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø (tyA kokiLechyA AvAjache sauMdary)
Lyrics of song of narration... -> ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ï‡•ã‡§ï‡§ø‡§≥‡•á‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§Ü‡§µ‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∏‡•å‡§Ç‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§®‡§æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ó‡§æ‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ö‡•á ‡§¨‡•ã‡§≤ (tyA kokiLechyA AvAjachyA sauMdaryAchyA varNanAchyA gANyAche bol)

title: Saying pasaMd hai ‡§™‡§∏‡§Ç‡§¶ ‡§π‡•à in Marathi
content:
In Hindi we say ‚Äú‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ù‡•á ‡§Ü‡§Æ ‡§™‡§∏‡§Ç‡§¶ ‡§π‡•à‚Äù (mujhe Am pasaMd hai), ‚Äú‡§â‡§∏‡•á ‡§ï‡•á‡§ï ‡§™‡§∏‡§Ç‡§¶ ‡§π‡•à(use kek pasaMd hai)‚Äù, ‚Äú‡§â‡§®‡•ç‡§π‡•á ‡§ï‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§™‡§∏‡§Ç‡§¶ ‡§•‡•á ( unhe kutte pasMd the)
As we can see the verb ‚Äú‡§™‡§∏‡§Ç‡§¶ ‡§π‡•ã‡§®‡§æ‚Äù ( pasaMd honA ) is formed as per the noun. And 2nd ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä (vibhaktI ) is used to indicate who likes.
e.g. ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ù‡•á/‡§á‡§∏‡•á/‡§â‡§∏‡•á/‡§π‡§Æ‡•á/‡§â‡§®‡•ç‡§π‡•á ‡§Ü‡§Æ ‡§™‡§∏‡§Ç‡§¶ ‡§π‡•à
In Marathi same rules are followed. The verb is ‡§Ü‡§µ‡§°‡§£‡•á ( AvaDaNe ).
‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ù‡•á ‡§Ü‡§Æ ‡§™‡§∏‡§Ç‡§¶ ‡§π‡•à (mujhe Am pasaMd hai)
‡§Æ‡§≤‡§æ ‡§Ü‡§Ç‡§¨‡§æ ‡§Ü‡§µ‡§°‡§§‡•ã (malA AMbA AvaDato )
‡§â‡§∏‡•á ‡§Æ‡•Ö‡§ó‡•ç‡§ó‡•Ä ‡§™‡§∏‡§Ç‡§¶ ‡§π‡•à ( use maggI pasaMd hai )
‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ ‡§Æ‡•Ö‡§ó‡•ç‡§ó‡•Ä ‡§Ü‡§µ‡§°‡§§‡•á (tyAlA maggI AvaDate )
‡§â‡§®‡•ç‡§π‡•á ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ ‡§™‡§∏‡§Ç‡§¶ ‡§Ü‡§Ø‡§æ ( unhe kAryakram pasaMd AyA )
‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç‡§®‡§æ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ ‡§Ü‡§µ‡§°‡§≤‡§æ (tyAMnA kAryakram AvaDalA)
‡§â‡§®‡•ç‡§π‡•á ‡§ñ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ ‡§™‡§∏‡§Ç‡§¶ ‡§Ü‡§Ø‡•á‡§ó‡§æ ( unhe khAnA pasaMd AyegA )
‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç‡§®‡§æ ‡§ú‡•á‡§µ‡§£ ‡§Ü‡§µ‡§°‡•á‡§≤ (tyAMnA jevaN AvaDel)
‡§â‡§∏‡•á ‡§ï‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§™‡§∏‡§Ç‡§¶ ‡§Ü‡§Ø‡•á ( use kutte pasaMd Aye )
‡§§‡•Ä‡§≤‡§æ ‡§ï‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á ‡§Ü‡§µ‡§°‡§≤‡•á ( tIlA kutre AvaDale )
‡§â‡§∏‡•á ‡§ï‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§™‡§∏‡§Ç‡§¶ ‡§•‡•á ( use kutte pasaMd the )
‡§§‡•Ä‡§≤‡§æ ‡§ï‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á ‡§Ü‡§µ‡§°‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ö‡•á ( tIlA kutre AvaDAyache )

title: Saying tum aap in Marathi ‡§§‡•Ç-‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ-‡§Ü‡§™ ‡§§‡•Ç-‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡•Ä
content:
‡§Ü‡§™ (Ap) or ‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ (tum) in Hindi is ‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡•Ä (tumhI) or ‡§Ü‡§™‡§£ (ApaN) in Marathi.
‚Äú‡§§‡•Ç‚Äù in Hindi is ‚Äú‡§§‡•Ç‚Äù in Marathi as well.
But do understand the difference in their usage especially its social background.
In Hindi, by default you address anyone else with respect i.e call him ‚Äú‡§Ü‡§™‚Äù or ‚Äú‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‚Äù. And only when you do not want to show respect or show a very friendly relation you will address that person as ‚Äú‡§§‡•Ç‚Äù.
In Marathi, it is opposite. By default, you will address anyone with ‚Äú‡§§‡•Ç‚Äù. It does not show disrespect at all. It is natural for a native Marathi speaker to address son, daughter, brother, sister, cousin, mother, grandmother, unknown person of same age etc. with ‚Äú‡§§‡•Ç‚Äù.
So when you translate a sentence from Hindi to Marathi, do NOT always translate ‚Äú‡§Ü‡§™‚Äù or ‚Äú‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‚Äù with ‚Äú‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡•Ä‚Äù. It might sound unnatural in Marathi. So think, how closely you are related with the person in front of you and then better to go for ‚Äú‡§§‡•Ç‚Äù.
That is why in this blog, I have given examples using ‚Äú‡§§‡•Ç‚Äù in Hindi. So a sentence using ‚Äú‡§Ü‡§™‚Äù or ‚Äú‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‚Äù should be the first thought in Hindi using ‚Äú‡§§‡•Ç‚Äù and then go for Marathi translation.
Only when you have to show respect explicitly, you will use ‚Äú‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡•Ä‚Äù. So generally father, grandfather, teacher, boss, unknown person, an elder person are addressed with ‚Äú‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡•Ä‚Äù.
At home/in family relationships whom to call ‡§§‡•Ç/‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡•Ä is decided by tradition of that family and it is personal choice. Nowadays in many families (including mine) children address their mother & father as ‚Äú‡§§‡•Ç‚Äù.

title: Sentences using "If-Then" Style 2
content:
In previous lesson we have learned how to say ‚ÄúIf‚Ä¶ then..‚Äù kind of sentences.
Sentence using ‚ÄúIf-Then‚Äù
In the second half of the above lesson we have seen that¬† ‚ÄúIf-Then‚Äù structure can be used to predict the future also. i.e. to indicate what will be the effect if some action is taken.¬†Same type of sentences can also be prepared using different style which is seen more in formal text, news or old style writing. This style is rarely used in day to day communication.
We use past tense sentence as a base. And then change the suffix of verb root to ‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏(lyAs)
e.g.¬†He spoke -> ‡§§‡•ã ‡§¨‡•ã‡§≤‡§≤‡§æ (to bolalA)
Here, pronoun is ‡§§‡•ã(to). Verb form is ‡§¨‡•ã‡§≤‡§≤‡§æ (bolalA). Verb root is ‡§¨‡•ã‡§≤(bol) and suffix is ‡§≤‡§æ(lA). When we change suffix to ‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏(lyAs); it becomes ‡§¨‡•ã‡§≤‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏ (bolalyAas)
So the sentence becomes ‡§§‡•ã ‡§¨‡•ã‡§≤‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏ (to bolalyAas) which is English is ‚ÄúIf he speaks‚Äù
Another example

title: Sentences using "would" in Marathi
content:
At the outset let me clarify that there is no exact/one-to-one replacement of modal verb ‚Äúwould‚Äù in Marathi.
In English, ‚Äúwould‚Äù is used in different ways to indicate different shades of meaning. Depending on the type of sentences are formed differently in Marathi.
Generally ‚Äúwould‚Äù is used in these type of sentences :
To talk about the past.
In place of ‚ÄúUsed to‚Äù phrase.
To talk about unreal situations
Conditional sentences
For politeness.
Let‚Äôs see how sentences are formed differently in Marathi.

title: Sentences with person or living things as object
content: Sentences with person or living things as object
intro: When the object is a person or living thing, use Preposition "To" (‡§≤‡§æ/‡§®‡§æ) with the object. In simple past and perfect tenses, verb form is always neuter-singular.

blocks.heading: Point 1: Use Preposition To
blocks.content:
For inanimate objects: I see dog -> ‡§Æ‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ ‡§¨‡§ò‡§§‡•ã (mI kutrA baghato). For a person (Kaushik): ‡§Æ‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•å‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï ‡§¨‡§ò‡§§‡•ã (mI kaushik baghato) is grammatically correct but not natural. When talking about a person, use **‡§≤‡§æ** (lA) with singular/**‡§®‡§æ** (nA) with plural or the corresponding pronoun form.

Like English "I see him" not "I see he":
- I see Kaushik -> ‡§Æ‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•å‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï‡§≤‡§æ ‡§¨‡§ò‡§§‡•ã (mI kaushikalA baghato)
- I see him -> ‡§Æ‡•Ä ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ ‡§¨‡§ò‡§§‡•ã (mI tyAlA baghato)
- He sees me -> ‡§§‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§≤‡§æ ‡§¨‡§ò‡§§‡•ã (to malA baghato)
- He is shaking her -> ‡§§‡•ã ‡§§‡•Ä‡§≤‡§æ ‡§π‡§≤‡§µ‡§§‡•ã ‡§Ü‡§π‡•á (to tIlA halavato Ahe)

blocks.heading: Point 2a: Simple past - verb always neuter-singular
blocks.content:
For person/living object, verb form is **always neuter-singular** regardless of object gender/plural:
- I saw Kaushik -> ‡§Æ‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•å‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï‡§≤‡§æ ‡§¨‡§ò‡§ø‡§§‡§≤‡•á (mI kaushikalA baghitale) (not ‡§¨‡§ò‡§ø‡§§‡§≤‡§æ)
- I saw her -> ‡§Æ‡•Ä ‡§§‡•Ä‡§≤‡§æ ‡§¨‡§ò‡§ø‡§§‡§≤‡•á (mI tIlA baghitale)
- He shook students -> ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç‡§®‡§æ ‡§π‡§≤‡§µ‡§≤‡•á (tyAne vidyArthyAMnA halavale)

Same rule for Perfect tenses:
- I have seen Kaushik -> ‡§Æ‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•å‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï‡§≤‡§æ ‡§¨‡§ò‡§ø‡§§‡§≤‡•á ‡§Ü‡§π‡•á (mI kaushikalA baghitale Ahe)

While speaking any language the pronunciations can be slightly different than bookish/written language. We tend to use the short form of verbs or words.
e.g. in English

Examples in the simple present tense:
I am -> ‡§Æ‡•Ä ‡§Ü‡§π‡•á (mI Ahe) -> ‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§Ø‡•á (mIye)

2) In neuter gender words ending ‡§è (e) is pronounced as ‡§Ö‡§Ç (Am)
e.g.
‚ÄúLeaf‚Äù in Marathi is ‚Äú‡§™‡§æ‡§® ‚Äú(pAn). Its plural is ‚Äú‡§™‡§æ‡§®‡•á‚Äù(pAne).
While speaking ‚Äú‡§™‡§æ‡§®‡•á‚Äù(pAne) is pronounced as ‡§™‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç(pAnM)
The last ‡§®(n) with the dot on it is pronounced as a nasal sound.
Try to understand the pronunciation of last ‡§®(n) with the dot on it.
It is explained in details as ‚ÄúRule 8) Use of ‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞ to indicate a change in pronunciation in colloquial language.‚Äù in lesson related to the pronunciation of anusvAr
Pronunciation of Anusvar ‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞
More examples:
Trees -> ‡§ù‡§æ‡§°‡•á (jhADe ) -> ‡§ù‡§æ‡§°‡§Ç (jhADaM)
watches -> ‡§ò‡§°‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≥‡•á -> (ghaDyALe ) -> ‡§ò‡§°‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≥‡§Ç (ghaDyALM )
cupboards -> ‡§ï‡§™‡§æ‡§ü‡•á (kapATe) -> ‡§ï‡§™‡§æ‡§ü‡§Ç (kapATaM)
Same is case for adjectives if applied to neuter words
my song :- ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ù‡•á ‡§ó‡§æ‡§£‡•á ( mAjhe gANe ) -> ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ù‡§Ç ‡§ó‡§æ‡§£‡§Ç ( mAjhaM gANaM )
Her cupboard :- ‡§§‡•Ä‡§ö‡•á ‡§ï‡§™‡§æ‡§ü (tIche kapAT ) -> ‡§§‡•Ä‡§ö‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§™‡§æ‡§ü (tIchaM kapAT )
Green forest :- ‡§π‡§ø‡§∞‡§µ‡•á ‡§ú‡§Ç‡§ó‡§≤ (hirave jaMgal ) -> ‡§π‡§ø‡§∞‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§ú‡§Ç‡§ó‡§≤ (hiravaM jaMgal )
3) If subject or object according to which the form of the verb is created, is of neuter gender, then ending with ‡§è (e) is pronounced as ‡§Ö‡§Ç (Am).
The way of pronunciation is the same as we have seen in the second rule.
Let‚Äôs see its applicability.
e.g.
That tree moves -> ‡§§‡•á ‡§ù‡§æ‡§° ‡§π‡§≤‡§§‡•á (te jhAD halate)
Here, the object is ‚Äú‡§ù‡§æ‡§°‚Äù (jhAD) which is neuter gender.
So verb ‡§π‡§≤‡§§‡•á (halate) can be pronounced as ‡§π‡§≤‡§§‡§Ç (halataM)
This rule is applicable only when subject or object according to which verb is formed, is of neuter gender. Not otherwise.
e.g.
That girl moves -> ‡§§‡•Ä ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§≤‡§ó‡•Ä ‡§π‡§≤‡§§‡•á (tI mulagI halate)
Here subject according to which verb is formed is girls i.e. feminine. So we will NOT say ‡§π‡§≤‡§§‡§Ç (halataM)
Other examples will make it clear:
As we had seen in the section of ‚ÄúGiving instructions formally‚Äù, suppose there is instruction Please tell your name -> ‡§Ü‡§™‡§≤‡•á ‡§®‡§æ‡§µ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§µ‡•á (Apale nAv sAMgAve)
Here, the object is ‚Äú‡§®‡§æ‡§µ‚Äù (nAv). It is of neuter gender. So verb ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§µ‡•á(sAMgAve) can be pronounced as ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§µ‡§Ç(sAMgAvaM)
I want chocolate -> ‡§Æ‡§≤‡§æ ‡§ö‡•â‡§ï‡§≤‡•á‡§ü ‡§π‡§µ‡•á ‡§Ü‡§π‡•á (malA ch~okaleT have Ahe ) ‡§ö‡•â‡§ï‡§≤‡•á‡§ü is of neuter gender, so ‡§π‡§µ‡•á(have ) can be pronounced as ‡§π‡§µ‡§Ç(havaM)
Example applying rule 3 and then rule 1
That child is asking -> ‡§§‡•á ‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§≤ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡§§‡•á ‡§Ü‡§π‡•á (te mUl vichArate Ahe) -> ‡§§‡•á ‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§≤ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡§§‡§Ç ‡§Ü‡§π‡•á (te mUl vichArataM Ahe) -> ‡§§‡•á ‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§≤ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡§§‡§Ç‡§Ø (te mUl vichArataMy)
I want chocolate -> ‡§Æ‡§≤‡§æ ‡§ö‡•â‡§ï‡§≤‡•á‡§ü ‡§π‡§µ‡•á ‡§Ü‡§π‡•á (malA ch~okaleT have Ahe ) -> ‡§Æ‡§≤‡§æ ‡§ö‡•â‡§ï‡§≤‡•á‡§ü ‡§π‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§Ü‡§π‡•á (malA ch~okaleT havaM Ahe ) -> ‡§Æ‡§≤‡§æ ‡§ö‡•â‡§ï‡§≤‡•á‡§ü ‡§π‡§µ‡§Ç‡§Ø (malA ch~okaleT havaMy)

title: Showing uncertainty using May, Might
content:
e.g. ‚ÄúHe may go‚Äù, ‚ÄúHe might say so‚Äù, ‚ÄúHe may not tell us‚Äù etc.
These sentences indicate uncertainty in future actions.
Interestingly, in usual Marathi there no special form to indicate uncertainty in future action.
In Marathi, the sentence is formed in the simple future tense, but a word like ‡§ï‡§¶‡§æ‡§ö‡§ø‡§§ (kadAchit), ‡§è‡§ñ‡§æ‡§¶‡§µ‡•á‡§≥‡•á‡§∏ (ekhAdaveLes), etc. are said to indicate uncertainty.
Example:
He may go -> Probably, he will go -> ‡§ï‡§¶‡§æ‡§ö‡§ø‡§§ ‡§§‡•ã ‡§ú‡§æ‡§à‡§≤ ( kadAchit to jAIl )
I may sing -> Probably; I will sing -> ‡§è‡§ñ‡§æ‡§¶‡§µ‡•á‡§≥‡•á‡§∏ ‡§Æ‡•Ä ‡§ó‡§æ‡§à‡§® ( ekhAdaveLes mI gAIn )
He might come -> Mostly, he will come -> ‡§¨‡§π‡•Å‡§§‡•á‡§ï ‡§§‡•ã ‡§Ø‡•á‡§à‡§≤ ( bahutek to yeIl )
‚ÄúMight‚Äù is used to show uncertainty in past action.
e.g. ‚ÄúHe might have finished it yesterday‚Äù, ‚ÄúHe might have written this‚Äù

title: Simple Future Tense in Marathi
content: Simple Future Tense in Marathi
intro: Similar to Simple Present, the structure is: Pronoun + verb + suffix.

blocks.heading: Structure
blocks.content:
Similar to Simple present tense, the Simple future tense also has the same sentence structure: **Pronoun followed by verb + suffix**.

**Example 1:** For I(male/female) the suffix is ‡§è‡§® (en). ‡§ö‡§æ‡§≤(chAl) + ‡§è‡§® = ‡§ö‡§æ‡§≤‡•á‡§® (chAlen). "I will walk" -> ‡§Æ‡•Ä ‡§ö‡§æ‡§≤‡•á‡§® (mI chAlen)

**Example 2:** For "We" the suffix is ‡§ä (U). ‡§ö‡§æ‡§≤(chAl) + ‡§ä = ‡§ö‡§æ‡§≤‡•Ç (chAlU). "We will walk" -> ‡§Ü‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡•Ä ‡§ö‡§æ‡§≤‡•Ç (AmhI chAlU)

**Example 3:** For "They" the suffix is ‡§§‡•Ä‡§≤ (tIl). ‡§ö‡§æ‡§≤(chAl) + ‡§§‡•Ä‡§≤ = ‡§ö‡§æ‡§≤‡§§‡•Ä‡§≤ (chAlatIl). "They will walk" -> ‡§§‡•á ‡§ö‡§æ‡§≤‡§§‡•Ä‡§≤ (te chAlatIl)

The form of "to Be" i.e. ‡§Ö‡§∏‡§£‡•á (asaNe) also follows the same rule. So they are not irregular as in Simple tense.

I will be -> ‡§Æ‡•Ä ‡§Ö‡§∏+‡§è‡§® -> ‡§Æ‡•Ä ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•á‡§®
We will be -> ‡§Ü‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡•Ä ‡§Ö‡§∏+‡§ä -> ‡§Ü‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡•Ä ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•Ç
They will be -> ‡§§‡•á/‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ/‡§§‡•Ä ‡§Ö‡§∏+‡§§‡•Ä‡§≤ -> ‡§§‡•á/‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ/‡§§‡•Ä ‡§Ö‡§∏‡§§‡•Ä‡§≤

blocks.heading: Suffix and ‡§Ö‡§∏‡§£‡•á forms for Simple Future
Explanation: Multiple suffixes
blocks.content:
**1) For "I":** a) Verbs ending with ‡§Ö(a): both ‡§è‡§® and ‡§à‡§® can be used. ‡§¨‡•ã‡§≤‡•á‡§® & ‡§¨‡•ã‡§≤‡•Ä‡§®, ‡§ï‡§∞‡•á‡§® & ‡§ï‡§∞‡•Ä‡§® are correct. b) Verbs NOT ending with ‡§Ö(a): only ‡§à‡§®. ‡§¶‡•á‡§à‡§®, ‡§π‡•ã‡§à‡§® are correct; ‡§¶‡•á‡§è‡§®, ‡§π‡•ã‡§è‡§® are incorrect.

**2) For ‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡•Ä (You plural):** a) Verbs ending with ‡§Ö(a): only ‡§Ü‡§≤. ‡§¨‡•ã‡§≤‡§æ‡§≤, ‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ‡§≤. b) Verbs ending with ‡§Ü(A): ‡§Ü‡§≤ but no repetition. ‡§ú‡§æ+‡§Ü‡§≤=‡§ú‡§æ‡§≤ (not ‡§ú‡§æ‡§Ü‡§≤). c) Verbs not ending with ‡§Ö/‡§Ü: only ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≤. ‡§¶‡•á->‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≤, ‡§™‡§ø->‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≤. ‡§π‡•ã is exceptional: ‡§µ‡•ç‡§π‡§æ‡§≤.

**3) For He/She/It:** a) Verbs ending with ‡§Ö(a): only ‡§è‡§≤. ‡§¨‡•ã‡§≤‡•á‡§≤, ‡§ï‡§∞‡•á‡§≤. b) Verbs NOT ending with ‡§Ö: only ‡§à‡§≤. ‡§¶‡•á‡§à‡§≤, ‡§π‡•ã‡§à‡§≤.

**4) Verbs ending with ‡§â(u):** Add ‡§µ(v) before suffix. ‡§ß‡•Å+‡§µ+‡§è‡§®->‡§ß‡•Å‡§µ‡•á‡§®. There are hardly any such verbs.

title: Simple Past Tense in Marathi - Part 1 (Verbs without noun)
content: Simple Past Tense in Marathi - Part 1 (Verbs without noun)
intro: For verbs without object, verb is formed according to gender of the subject. Pay extra attention‚Äîpast tense has different structure and many exceptions.

blocks.heading: Two types of statements
blocks.content:
In Simple Present, Continuous Present, Simple Future, and Continuous future tense; the verb is formed depending on the Nominative (doer). In past tense there is some difference.

**Type 1:** Verbs which have nouns/object. e.g. I ate mango. (I = subject, mango = object)
**Type 2:** Verbs which do not have nouns/object. e.g. I speak. (verb speak does not need object)

For Type 1: verb is formed according to gender of the object.
For Type 2: verb is formed according to gender of Pronoun/subject.

**Sentence without Object:** Pronoun + Verb + Suffix for Simple Past Tense

Example: For "We" the suffix is ‡§≤‡•ã (lo). ‡§ö‡§æ‡§≤(chAl) + ‡§≤‡•ã = ‡§ö‡§æ‡§≤‡§≤‡•ã (chAlalo). We walked -> ‡§Ü‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡•Ä ‡§ö‡§æ‡§≤‡§≤‡•ã (AmhI chAlalo)

blocks.heading: Suffixes for Simple Past (verbs without object)
Exceptions
blocks.content:
Pay more attention to verbs ‡§¨‡§ò (bagh), ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ó (sAMg), ‡§ï‡§∞ (kar), ‡§ñ‡§æ (khA), etc. In past tense the verb itself changes first, then suffixes are added.

Example: "He saw movie" - verb ‡§¨‡§ò changes to ‡§¨‡§ò‡§ø‡§§. So ‡§¨‡§ò‡§ø‡§§‡§≤‡§æ (baghitalA) not ‡§¨‡§ò‡§≤‡§æ.

These forms are used in Perfect tenses also.

title: Simple Past Tense in Marathi - Part 2 (Verbs with object)
content: Simple Past Tense in Marathi - Part 2 (Verbs with object)
intro: For verbs with object, the verb is formed as per gender and singular/plural of the object. The subject (doer) takes special forms.

blocks.heading: Rule for forming verb
blocks.content:
The verb is formed as per gender and singular/plural of the **object**.

**Example 1:** "I read letter". Object = letter (neuter, like "it"). Suffix for "it" is ‡§≤‡•á (le). ‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö(vAch)+‡§≤‡•á = ‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡§≤‡•á (vAchale). ‡§Æ‡•Ä ‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡§≤‡•á

**Example 2:** "I opened box". Object = box (masculine). Suffix for "he" is ‡§≤‡§æ (lA). ‡§â‡§ò‡§°(ughaD)+‡§≤‡§æ = ‡§â‡§ò‡§°‡§≤‡§æ. ‡§Æ‡•Ä ‡§ñ‡•ã‡§ï‡§æ ‡§â‡§ò‡§°‡§≤‡§æ

**Example 3:** "I opened boxes". Object = boxes (masculine plural). Suffix for They(m.) is ‡§≤‡•á (le). ‡§â‡§ò‡§°+‡§≤‡•á = ‡§â‡§ò‡§°‡§≤‡•á. ‡§Æ‡•Ä ‡§ñ‡•ã‡§ï‡•á ‡§â‡§ò‡§°‡§≤‡•á

blocks.heading: Rule for forms of subject (doer)
blocks.content:
1) For I, We, You: no change.
2) For "he": use ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•á (tyAne)
3) For "she": use ‡§§‡•Ä‡§®‡•á (tIne)

title: Simple Present Tense in Marathi
content: Simple Present Tense in Marathi
intro: Learn sentence formation: Pronoun + verb + suffix. The suffix depends on the pronoun and gender.

blocks.heading: Introduction
blocks.content:
Today we will finally reach sentence formation. Let us learn Simple Present Tense in Marathi.

In English, a boy will say "I go". In Marathi, he will say ‡§Æ‡•Ä ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡•ã (mI jAto).
As we have seen before, the verb "Go" is ‡§ú‡§æ (jA) in Marathi. So for Simple Present tense, we suffix ‡§§‡•ã (to) to the verb. Simple!

‡§ú‡§æ (jA) + ‡§§‡•ã (to) = ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡•ã (jAto)

Similarly, a girl will say ‡§Æ‡•Ä ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡•á (mI jAte). Note that there is a different suffix based on the gender of the speaker. For the feminine, the suffix is ‡§§‡•á (te).

‡§ú‡§æ (jA) + ‡§§‡•á (te) = ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡•á (jAte)

So the formula for forming a sentence is: **Pronoun + verb + suffix**

content:
I think enough of the serious discussion about grammar. üôÇ üôÇ
Let‚Äôs start with simple sentences. Before starting I want to clarify a few things.
Examples given below follow the rules we have discussed so far. So grammar is not explained again. I would request you to read each sentence carefully and identify how the form of a particular word or verb is created.
Wherever a new concept or exception is introduced, I will try to explain it there.
Please note the Marathi translation may not be an exact word-to-word translation.
e.g. when asking about someone‚Äôs height in English we say ‚ÄúHow long are you?‚Äú but Marathi sentence will be similar to asking ‚ÄúWhat is your height‚Äù. So you should sense the difference.
You know that form of verb changes depending on gender and multiplicity.
So wherever applicable I have mentioned gender in brackets followed by the corresponding version of the sentence.
Because of British rule in India, English is learned and used widely throughout India. So the use of English words is quite common. In many cases, English words are natural choice than original Marathi words !!
In Marathi to say something with respect, the sentence is formed using the plural.
In English when telling about a friend you will say, ‚ÄúHe goes to work‚Äù. While speaking about an elderly person with respect you will still say ‚ÄúHe goes to work‚Äù. But in Marathi second sentence (with respect) will form like saying ‚ÄúThey go to work‚Äù.
To Indicate this I have marked such sentence as ‚ÄúTo Man‚Äù or ‚ÄúTo Lady‚Äù. So these are ‚Äúwith respect‚Äù versions.

title: Tips to Learn Marathi ‡§Æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§†‡•Ä ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∑‡§æ ‡§∏‡§ø‡§ñ‡§®‡•á‡§ï‡•á ‡§®‡•Å‡§∏‡•ç‡§ñ‡•á marathi bhasha sikhaneke nuskhe
Tips to Learn Marathi (rather any new language)
content:
Many users of this blog asked me about tips to Learn Marathi fast. So I would like to share my thoughts about it. These are the things which I followed when I learned Tamil and Gujarati myself. I learned the basics of these languages through the book
Learn Tamil through Marathi by Balaji publication
Rapidex Tamil-Hindi learning course
and then developed myself without anybody‚Äôs personal help.
So these are proven methods which will help you to learn not only Marathi but any new language.
You can surely try it.
Learn Grammar :
Read the blog at least once so that you will get to know different grammar rules. You may not remember everything but concepts will be at the back of your mind. As and when you keep reading the blog further or reading Marathi text elsewhere you will be able to relate concepts you had read before. When you will frequently come across the use of these grammar rules, you will remember it. Learning grammar alone can make you an independent speaker. No matter how many ready-made sentences you read, until you understand the rule behind it you will not be able to form sentences yourself. Few people do not like to study grammar, but they keep listening/reading the language and sense the grammar. This is the same way a baby learns the mother tongue without formally knowing grammar rules. Whatever approach suits you; but learn grammar.
Watch Marathi news channel:
Read or listen to the news in any language you know, and then watch the same news in Marathi. As you already know the news, listening to it again in Marathi will be easy to understand. You can relate the words. Thus learn new words. In news channels formal Marathi language is used so it will be easy to understand.
Start reading newspaper:
It has the same benefit as watching the news channel. It has formal language and news knowing you can relate to text faster.
Buy dictionaries:
Buy 2 dictionaries
English-Marathi and Marathi-English.
This will be helpful while reading newspaper. Without dictionaries you can not increase your vocabulary.Dictionaries are available online as well.
Then start watching Marathi serials ( daily-soaps ) :
Then start viewing daily Marathi serials on Marathi channels. These serials have conversations happening in your day to day life. This is very useful. Go for serious nature programs.
Do not try Marathi movies initially
.
Also Do not go for comedy serials/dramas initially
. To understand comedy, one needs to have very good knowledge of the language (hidden meanings, double meanings, etc. ) and social context. So comedy serials/movies will not help you initially. Rather it will discourage you as you may not be able to enjoy it.
Start reading Marathi magazines
Unless you dare to speak you can not be confident:
Wherever possible speak in Marathi with whatever knowledge you have. Ask another person to rectify you. Understand mistake and try again. Keep trying, and one day you will realize that you are speaking without any mistake.
Practice makes man perfect:
As applicable in any aspect of life, this rule is valid in the language learning paradigm as well.
Read more to increase vocabulary.
Listen more to increase understanding capacity.
Talk more to make you confident
. While reading you follow your own pace. You will have time to read the sentence, understand it, check new words and thus increase vocabulary. Watching/Listening Marathi helps you increase your capacity to understand others but while listening to others we tend to gloss over the details i.e. new words.
So two things help in two different ways
Remember Marathi and other Indian languages have dialects. So focus on standard Marathi first :
I think in English only pronunciation of differs depending on region or country but basic grammar rules do not change.
But in India Marathi and all other Indian languages have dialects. Each dialect can have little different grammar rules for verb formation. Each dialect can have a different set of words. That is why you feel the native Marathi speaker sounds different than what you have learned.
Do not get confused. Focus on standard Marathi. Be confident in it then you will be able to relate the dialect and understand it correctly. Even native speaker of one Marathi dialect generally is not able to speak other dialect, though he understands it.
So be confident in Standard Marathi, then try just understanding other dialect and you may continue using your dialect( that is standard Marathi )

content:
Consider the sentence ‚ÄúI will finish it tomorrow‚Äù. Now if you want to emphasize the time you will say ‚ÄúI will finish it tomorrow itself‚Äù.
Consider the sentence ‚ÄúHe told me that he got a lottery‚Äù. Now to emphasize who told you, you will say ‚ÄúHe himself told me he got lottery‚Äù.
Sometimes Indians tend to create such sentences as ‚ÄúHe only told me‚Äù, ‚ÄúYou only asked me close door‚Äù etc.
In Marathi, we use ‡§ö(ch) to emphasize on the word. ‡§ö(ch) is a one-size-fits-all kind of suffix. You can add it ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§æ (kartA) i.e. doer of the action, ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ (karm) noun, verb or any other word which you want to emphasize.
