title: Using "Let" and "Shall we"
content:
Suppose we want to call our friends for some action, we will say ‚ÄúLet us go‚Äù, ‚ÄúLet us start lunch‚Äù etc.
In Marathi such form is created by suffixing ‚Äú‡§ä‡§Ø‡§æ‚Äù (UyA) to the verb. Also generally sentence is started with ‡§ö‡§≤‡§æ (chalA) which is a kind of exclamation or call for action.
Examples:
Let‚Äôs play:- ‡§ö‡§≤‡§æ, ‡§Ü‡§™‡§£ ‡§ñ‡•á‡§≥‡•Ç‡§Ø‡§æ (chalA, ApaN kheLUyA)
Let‚Äôs go:- ‡§ö‡§≤‡§æ, ‡§Ü‡§™‡§£ ‡§ú‡§æ‡§ä‡§Ø‡§æ (chalA, ApaN jAUyA)
‚Äú‡§Ü‡§™‡§£‚Äù can be omitted.
Let‚Äôs speak:- ‡§ö‡§≤‡§æ, ‡§¨‡•ã‡§≤‡•Ç‡§Ø‡§æ
Negative sentence:
The negative sentence can be formed by adding ‚Äú‡§®‡§ï‡•ã‚Äù (nako) before the verb. Generally, ‡§ö‡§≤‡§æ (chalA) will not be used as we are not calling for any action.
Examples:
Let‚Äôs not play:- ‡§Ü‡§™‡§£ ‡§®‡§ï‡•ã ‡§ñ‡•á‡§≥‡•Ç‡§Ø‡§æ (ApaN nako kheLUyA)
Let‚Äôs not go:- ‡§Ü‡§™‡§£ ‡§®‡§ï‡•ã ‡§ú‡§æ‡§ä‡§Ø‡§æ (ApaN nako jAUyA)
Let‚Äôs not speak:- ‡§®‡§ï‡•ã ‡§¨‡•ã‡§≤‡•Ç‡§Ø‡§æ (nako bolUyA )

title: Using May to express wish
content:
In English we say ‚ÄúMay God bless you‚Äù, ‚ÄúMay he help you‚Äù, ‚ÄúMay door open soon‚Äù. Here we have used ‚Äúmay‚Äù express wish.
In Marathi, we say such wishes by appending ‡§ì(o) for singular and ‡§ì‡§§(ot) to plural.
e.g.
for verb do i.e. ‡§ï‡§∞‡§£‡•á(karaNe) forms are ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ã(karo) and ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ã‡§§ (karot)
for verb speak i.e. ‡§¨‡•ã‡§≤‡§£‡•á(bolaNe) forms are ‡§¨‡•ã‡§≤‡•ã(bolo) and ‡§¨‡•ã‡§≤‡•ã‡§§ (bolot)
For verbs not ending with ‡§Ö(a) we append ‡§µ‡•ã(vo) for singular and ‡§µ‡•ã‡§§(vot) for plural.
for verb give i.e.‡§¶‡•á‡§£‡•á (deNe) forms are ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡•ã ( devo ) and ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡•ã‡§§ ( devot )
for verb become i.e ‡§π‡•ã‡§£‡•á ( hoNe ) forms are ‡§π‡•ã‡§µ‡•ã ( hovo ) and ‡§π‡•ã‡§µ‡•ã‡§§ ( hovot )
May God bless you -> ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ ‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ ‡§Ü‡§∂‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶ ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡•ã ( dev tumhAlA AshirvAd devo )
May he help you -> ‡§§‡•ã ‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§¶‡§§ ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ã ( to tumhAlA madat karo )
May they help you -> ‡§§‡•á ‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§¶‡§§ ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ã‡§§ ( te tumhAlA madat karot )
May new year be happy to you -> ‡§®‡§µ‡•Ä‡§® ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑ ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ñ‡§¶‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ï ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ã ( navIn varSh sukhadAyak aso )
May shop open soon -> ‡§¶‡•Å‡§ï‡§æ‡§® ‡§≤‡§µ‡§ï‡§∞ ‡§â‡§ò‡§°‡•ã ( dukAn lavakar ughaDo)
Give above is the word to word translation of ‚ÄúMay God bless you‚Äù, but as custom, in Marathi, we say ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ ‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡§ö‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ã ( dev tumachaM bhalaM karo )
In Marathi, we generally use this form only for third-person. Not with first or second person i.e. not with ‡§Æ‡•Ä, ‡§Ü‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡•Ä, ‡§§‡•Ç, ‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡•Ä.
So In English, we can form a sentence like ‚ÄúMay you help me‚Äù which will be in Marathi as ‡§§‡•Ç ‡§Æ‡§≤‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§¶‡§§ ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ã ( tU malA madat karo ). So though grammatically perfect, it sounds a bit irregular in Marathi.
Wish / To wish
‚ÄúWish‚Äù (noun) -> ‡§á‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§æ (ichCA) it is feminine-singular noun. To wish -> ‡§á‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§∏‡§£‡•á (ichCA asaNe)
The sentence using ‡§á‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§∏‡§£‡•á (ichCA asaNe) is similar to saying ‚ÄúIt is my wish that‚Ä¶ may/should‚Ä¶‚Äù
I wish he goes to school -> It is my wish that he should go to school -> ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ù‡•Ä ‡§Ö‡§∂‡•Ä ‡§á‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§æ ‡§Ü‡§π‡•á ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§§‡•ã ‡§∂‡§æ‡§≥‡•á‡§§ ‡§ó‡•á‡§≤‡§æ ‡§™‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§ú‡•á.(mAjhI ashI ichChA Ahe kI to shALet gelA pAhije.)
He wishes Kaushik wins -> It is his wish that may Kaushik win -> ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ö‡•Ä ‡§Ö‡§∂‡•Ä ‡§á‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§æ ‡§Ü‡§π‡•á ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•å‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï ‡§ú‡§ø‡§Ç‡§ï‡•ã(tyAchI ashI ichChA Ahe kI Kaushik jiMko)
It is his wish that Kaushik should win -> ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ö‡•Ä ‡§Ö‡§∂‡•Ä ‡§á‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§æ ‡§Ü‡§π‡•á ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•å‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï‡§®‡•á ‡§ú‡§ø‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•á (tyAchI ashI ichChA Ahe kI kaushikane jiMkAve)
With ‡§Ö‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ï(akarmak) verbs; when expressing wish; we create verb form as per gender and multiplicity of
subject
Subject
verb+ form of "‡§µ‡§æ" depending on gender and multiplicity of subject i.e.
‡§Ü‡§µ‡§æ-‡§Ü‡§µ‡•Ä-‡§Ü‡§µ‡•á-‡§Ü‡§µ‡•á-‡§Ü‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ-‡§Ü‡§µ‡•Ä  (AvA-AvI-Ave-Ave-AvyA-AvI)
‡§§‡•ã (to)

To speak:- ‡§¨‡•ã‡§≤‡§£‡•á (bolaNe) Froms will be ‡§¨‡•ã‡§≤‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ ‚Äì ‡§¨‡•ã‡§≤‡§æ‡§µ‡•Ä -‡§¨‡•ã‡§≤‡§æ‡§µ‡•á -‡§¨‡•ã‡§≤‡§æ‡§µ‡•á -‡§¨‡•ã‡§≤‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ -‡§¨‡•ã‡§≤‡§æ‡§µ‡•Ä (boAvA-boAvI-boAve-boAve-boAvyA-boAvI)
Examples:
I wish that he should win-> ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ù‡•Ä ‡§Ö‡§∂‡•Ä ‡§á‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§æ ‡§Ü‡§π‡•á ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§§‡•ã ‡§ú‡§ø‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ (mAjhI ashI ichChA Ahe kI to jiMkAvA)

He wishes that I(boy) win-> ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ö‡•Ä ‡§Ö‡§∂‡•Ä ‡§á‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§æ ‡§Ü‡§π‡•á ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§Æ‡•Ä ‡§ú‡§ø‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ (tyAchI ashI ichChA Ahe kI mI jiMkAvA)

1) If the verb does not end with sound ‡§Ö(a) then we simply omit ‡§Ü(A) and append‡§µ‡§æ-‡§µ‡•Ä-‡§µ‡•á-‡§µ‡•á-‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ-‡§µ‡•Ä (vA-vI-ve-ve-vyA-vI)

I wish that you(boy) should smile -> ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ù‡•Ä ‡§Ö‡§∂‡•Ä ‡§á‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§æ ‡§Ü‡§π‡•á ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§§‡•Ç ‡§π‡§∏‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏ (mAjhI ashi ichChA Ahe kI tU hasAvAs)

title: Using phrase "supposed to" in Marathi
content:
Sentences using the phrase
‚Äúsupposed to‚Äù
are generally said in
Marathi as if saying ‚Äúwant to‚Äù
.
e.g. I am supposed to meet him tomorrow -> I am want to meet him tomorrow -> ‡§Æ‡§≤‡§æ ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ ‡§â‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§≠‡•á‡§ü‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ö‡•á ‡§Ü‡§π‡•á ( malA tyAlA udyA bheTAyache Ahe)
Such sentences are discussed in this lesson.
Using ‚ÄúTo Want‚Äù/‚ÄùTo Need‚Äù with other verbs
However, sometimes you can find that sentences with ‚Äúsupposed to‚Äù are said little differently. Sentence structure is similar to the sentence with ‚Äúto want‚Äù; the only difference is in the form of the subject. As highlighted below.

title: Using phrase ‚Äúto keep doing‚Äù
content:
To indicate the continuity of action we use ‚ÄúTo keep doing‚Äù form of the sentence.
e.g
I keep trying even if I fail.
He kept speaking until all slept.
Do not stop, keep doing

Doer of action

title: Using plurals to indicate respect ‡§Ü‡§¶‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•Ä ‡§¨‡§π‡•Å‡§µ‡§ö‡§® (Adararthi bahuvachan )
content: Using plurals to indicate respect ‡§Ü‡§¶‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•Ä ‡§¨‡§π‡•Å‡§µ‡§ö‡§® (AdarArthI bahuvachan)
intro: In Marathi, plurals are used to indicate respect. This is called ‡§Ü‡§¶‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•Ä ‡§¨‡§π‡•Å‡§µ‡§ö‡§® (AdarArthI bahuvachan).

blocks.heading: Introduction
blocks.content:
While learning Marathi it is important to understand the customs or traditions of the Marathi community which get reflected in language. One important aspect to learn is how elders are addressed in Marathi.

In Marathi, plurals are used to indicate respect. This is called **‡§Ü‡§¶‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•Ä ‡§¨‡§π‡•Å‡§µ‡§ö‡§®** (AdarArthI bahuvachan).

blocks.heading: Example: Prime Minister
blocks.content:
If you are talking about the Prime Minister of your country. In English, you will say "He is Prime Minister. He is speaking".

In Marathi, "He" is ‡§§‡•ã (to). Literal translation: ‡§§‡•ã ‡§™‡§Ç‡§§‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ß‡§æ‡§® ‡§Ü‡§π‡•á. ‡§§‡•ã ‡§¨‡•ã‡§≤‡§§ ‡§Ü‡§π‡•á (to paMtapradhAn Ahe. to bolat Ahe)

But because you are talking about P.M. with respect, you use the plural of ‡§§‡•ã (to) which is ‡§§‡•á (te):
‡§§‡•á ‡§™‡§Ç‡§§‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ß‡§æ‡§® ‡§Ü‡§π‡•á‡§§. ‡§§‡•á ‡§¨‡•ã‡§≤‡§§ ‡§Ü‡§π‡•á‡§§ (te paMtapradhAn Ahet. te bolat Ahet)

Literally in English: "They are Prime Minister. They are speaking" ‚Äî which sounds odd in English, but in Marathi it is the natural and correct way.

blocks.heading: Examples with ‡§§‡•Ä and ‡§§‡•Ç
blocks.content:
**Lady:** She is good ‚Üí ‡§§‡•Ä ‡§ö‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ó‡§≤‡•Ä ‡§Ü‡§π‡•á (tI chAMgalI Ahe)
With respect (plural of ‡§§‡•Ä is ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ): ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ö‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ó‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§Ü‡§π‡•á‡§§ (tyA chAMgalyA Ahet)

**How are you:** ‡§§‡•Ç ‡§ï‡§∏‡§æ ‡§Ü‡§π‡•á‡§∏ (tU kasA Ahes)
With respect (plural of ‡§§‡•Ç is ‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡•Ä): ‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡•Ä ‡§ï‡§∏‡•á ‡§Ü‡§π‡§æ‡§§ (tumhI kase AhAt)

blocks.heading: Historical note: ‡§Ü‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡•Ä for self
blocks.content:
In old times, few learned or rich persons used to address themselves with respect, using ‡§Ü‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡•Ä (AmhI) while talking about themselves.

I am coming ‚Üí ‡§Æ‡•Ä ‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡•ã ‡§Ü‡§π‡•á (mI yeto Ahe)
Giving oneself respect they used: ‡§Ü‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡•Ä ‡§Ø‡•á‡§§ ‡§Ü‡§π‡•ã‡§§ (AmhI yet Ahot)

In editorials of Marathi newspapers, you will find the editor calling himself ‡§Ü‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡•Ä. But nowadays in day-to-day communication, nobody calls himself ‡§Ü‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡•Ä as it looks like boasting.

blocks.heading: Respect without pronouns
blocks.content:
Even if sentences do not have pronouns, they should be formed in plural way to indicate respect.

**Examples:**
- Shivaji Maharaj was great
  - Literal: ‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§ú‡•Ä ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§® ‡§π‡•ã‡§§‡§æ (shivAjI mahArAj mahAn hotA)
  - With respect: ‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§ú‡•Ä ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§® ‡§π‡•ã‡§§‡•á (shivAjI mahArAj mahAn hote)

- Kaushik is my teacher
  - Literal: ‡§ï‡•å‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ù‡§æ ‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ï ‡§Ü‡§π‡•á (kaushik mAjhA shikshak Ahe)
  - With respect: ‡§ï‡•å‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ù‡•á ‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ï ‡§Ü‡§π‡•á‡§§ (kaushik mAjhe shikshak Ahet)

**Note:** We do not use the plural of the main noun. Only the pronoun, adjective, and verb use plural form.
- Your mother is good (with respect): ‡§§‡•Å‡§ù‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§Ü‡§à ‡§ö‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ó‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§Ü‡§π‡•á‡§§ (tujhyA AI chAMgalyA Ahet) ‚Äî we use ‡§Ü‡§à, not ‡§Ü‡§Ø‡§æ
- She is my husband's sister: ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ù‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§®‡§£‡§Ç‡§¶ ‡§Ü‡§π‡•á‡§§ (tyA mAjhyA naNaMd Ahet) ‚Äî we do not use ‡§®‡§£‡§Ç‡§¶‡§æ (plural of ‡§®‡§£‡§Ç‡§¶)

**But** when you use a preposition with a noun, we use the plural:
- To mother (literal): ‡§Ü‡§à‡§≤‡§æ (AIlA)
- To mother (with respect): ‡§Ü‡§à‡§Ç‡§®‡§æ (AIMnA)
- For teacher (literal): ‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ï‡§æ‡§∏‡§æ‡§†‡•Ä (shikShakAsAThI)
- For teacher (with respect): ‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§†‡•Ä (shikShakAMsAThI)

blocks.heading: Using ‡§Ü‡§™‡§£ (ApaN) instead of ‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡•Ä (tumhI)
blocks.content:
When speaking very formally or in very formal written communication, instead of ‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡•Ä (tumhI) we use ‡§Ü‡§™‡§£ (ApaN). The rest of the sentence structure remains the same.

**Examples:**
- How are you?
  - With respect: ‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡•Ä ‡§ï‡§∏‡•á ‡§Ü‡§π‡§æ‡§§ (tumhI kase AhAt)
  - Very formal: ‡§Ü‡§™‡§£ ‡§ï‡§∏‡•á ‡§Ü‡§π‡§æ‡§§ (ApaN kase AhAt)

- You are doing work
  - With respect: ‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡•Ä ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§§ ‡§Ü‡§π‡§æ‡§§ (tumhI kAm karat AhAt)
  - Very formal: ‡§Ü‡§™‡§£ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§§ ‡§Ü‡§π‡§æ‡§§ (ApaN kAm karat AhAt)

- What do you want?
  - With respect: ‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§™‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§ú‡•á? (tumhAlA kAy pAhije)
  - Very formal: ‡§Ü‡§™‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§™‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§ú‡•á? (ApalyAlA kAy pAhije)

For ‡§Ö‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ï (akarmak) verbs; the object is assumed to be of neuter-singular gender

By using ‡§®‡§æ‡§π‡•Ä ‡§™‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§ú‡•á (nAhI pAhije ) we make the sentence negative.

title: Using verb "To remember" in Marathi
content:
In Marathi ‚Äú
To remember
‚Äù is
‡§Ü‡§†‡§µ‡§£‡•á
(AThavaNe)
There are three ways in which we use the verb ‚Äúto remember‚Äù
1) Suppose a teacher meets his student after many years and says ‚ÄúYou are from the batch of 1970, right? I remember you.‚Äù
2) A student living in a hostel writes a letter to his mother; ‚ÄúWhenever I eat food at canteen I remember dishes you used to cook. I miss you.‚Äù
3) A person helped you in your bad time. You will say to him; ‚ÄúThank you, friend. I will always remember your favor‚Äù.
In all the sentence we have used verb remember, but there is a subtle difference in every use.
In the first sentence, you say you have not forgotten something.
In the second case, you say one event triggers or brings back the memory of some other event.
In the third sentence, you explicitly assure of keeping something in mind.
In Marathi sentence is formed differently in every case.

content: Verbs in Marathi
intro: Learn common Marathi verbs. Just saying the verb is asking someone to do that action ‚Äî e.g. ‡§Ø‡•á (ye) = Come!

blocks.heading: Introduction
blocks.content:
Friends, let us move a step ahead in learning sentence formation in Marathi. We will talk about verbs in Marathi.

In English, some verbs are: to go; to come; to speak; to sit; to eat, etc.
In Marathi some verbs are: ‡§Ø‡•á‡§£‡•á (yeNe), ‡§ú‡§æ‡§£‡•á (jANe), ‡§¨‡•ã‡§≤‡§£‡•á (bolaNe), ‡§¨‡§∏‡§£‡•á (basaNe), ‡§ñ‡§æ‡§£‡•á (khANe) etc.

In most cases, while using the verb in an English sentence, we strip "to" out of it. e.g. "To come" is used as "I come" etc. The same way in Marathi, the ending ‡§£‡•á (Ne) is stripped in the sentence.

Like in English, just saying the verb is asking someone to do that action. When you say "Come!" you are asking someone to come. Same way in Marathi saying "‡§Ø‡•á (ye)" is asking someone to come. So by knowing the verbs you can easily request someone.

title: Verbs which use preposition "To" with subject and verb form as per object
content:
Before I begin, let me thank my student Ram Prakash for giving me the idea of this lesson.
Verbs which use the preposition ‚ÄúTo‚Äù with subject and verb form as per object
Consider the verbs ‚ÄúTo remember‚Äù, ‚ÄúTo like‚Äù, ‚ÄúTo get‚Äù. In English, sentences will be formed as follows
I remember He remembers, They remember‚Ä¶
I like, He likes, They like‚Ä¶
I get, He gets, They get‚Ä¶
As you see, the verb form changes as per the subject in the sentences (I, He, They in the above sentences).
In Marathi few verbs are exceptional. For such verbs the sentence structure is different.
The preposition ‚ÄúTo‚Äù is used with the subject. And the verb form is created as per the gender and multiplicity of the object.
‚ÄúTo get‚Äù i.e. ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§≥‡§£‡•á(miLaNe) is one such verb
e.g.
‚ÄúI get a prize‚Äù will be translated like saying ‚ÄúTo me a prize gets‚Äù
‚ÄúI get 10 prizes‚Äù will be translated like saying ‚ÄúTo me 10 prizes get‚Äù.
Observe that change in verb form from ‚Äúgets‚Äù to ‚Äúget‚Äù when object changed from singular (a prize) to plural (10 prizes) & preposition ‚ÄúTo‚Äù with the subject.
So in Marathi
I get a prize -> To me a prize gets -> ‡§Æ‡§≤‡§æ ‡§¨‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§∏ ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§≥‡§§‡•á (malA bakShis miLate)

title: Vowels, Consonants in Marathi and their pronunciation
content: Pronunciation conventions for Marathi alphabets. Learn vowels, consonants, and key pronunciation rules.
intro: Pronunciation conventions for Marathi alphabets. Each letter represents a consistent sound. Use the speaker buttons to hear pronunciation.

blocks.heading: Consonant Pronunciation Notes (‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç‡§ú‡§®)
blocks.content: Each consonant combines with a vowel sound to make syllables (e.g., ‡§ï + ‡§Ö = ‡§ï /ka/). Retroflex sounds (‡§ü, ‡§†, ‡§°, ‡§¢, ‡§£, ‡§≥) use tongue curled back (harder), represented by capital style in transliteration when needed. Some consonants like ‡§ô /·πÖ/ and ‡§û /√±a/ are nasal stops (nose sound) and different from ‡§® /na/.

blocks.heading: Key Pronunciation Rules
blocks.content:
**One letter = one sound:** Each Marathi letter generally represents a consistent sound.

**Vowel quality:** ‡§á /i/ is like "i" in sit, ‡§à /ƒ´/ is like "ee" in see. ‡§â /u/ and ‡§ä /≈´/ are like "oo" in foot and cool. ‡§è /e/ is a mid-front sound like ay in say. ‡§ê /ai/ is a diphthong like ai in time. ‡§ì /o/ is like o in go, ‡§î /au/ is like ow in cow.

**Retroflex vs dental:** t/T, d/D represent retroflex vs dental articulations (hard vs soft).

**Schwa behavior:** The inherent "a" vowel is often not pronounced at the end in real speech (schwa deletion variations).

title: Welcome to Learn Marathi from Hindi
content:
Learning Marathi through Hindi is very easy. Being conversant with Hindi has many advantages while learning Marathi.
1) Both languages use the same script i.e. Devanagari. So by default, you can read Marathi.
2) The beauty of Devanagari with respect to the Roman script is that the pronunciation is the same as what it is written. So you will not make mistake in pronunciation of Marathi words. So that part is automatically taken care of
3) Mostly the sentence formation rules (e.g. a sequence of the noun, verb etc.) in Marathi is the same as Hindi. So generally you map a Hindi sentence into Marathi word by word.
In short, you know Hindi means 80% you already know Marathi.
So in this coming lessons, we will try to cover up those 20% !!
In my blog for learning Marathi through English(
http://kaushiklele-learnmarathi.blogspot.in
)
I had explained grammar in detail. English is a completely different language, I thought it necessary to introduce a learner with grammar then slowly moving to simple sentences and then big conversations.
But as you know Hindi, I would directly start with Marathi sentences. You will be able to extract the grammar automatically. Wherever required I will explain the difference.
Also, many people who know Hindi want to grasp simple sentences quickly and develop their skills by more listening and reading. For them, learning grammar in detail is a discouraging factor.
So the approach is completely changing while learning Marathi from Hindi.
For some examples transliteration is given in Roman script is as well. This is for the convenience of search-ability on internet.

title: Welcome to world of Marathi
content:
Hello friends, welcome to my blog, ‚ÄúLearn Marathi through English-Hindi‚Äù.Here I am trying to introduce you to the fundamentals of Marathi through English. But at some places, I have taken the help of examples from Hindi.
Hindi and Marathi both follow the same script i.e. Devanagari. The pronunciation of letters is the same. So those who can read-write Hindi, for them reading Marathi is easy. They will save their time learning pronunciation. So if you know Hindi, this journey to learn Marathi will be comparatively easy. But those who do not know Hindi need not feel upset, but they just need to put little more effort learning script and pronunciation.
My own experience says that reading the language from its own script helps a lot. So learn the Devanagari script first. So learning Marathi will be easier if you read it directly from Devanagari instead of Romanized. For most of the examples, transliteration is given in Roman script is as well. This is for the convenience of search-ability on the internet.

title: Which-That / What-That sentences
content:
From the title, it might not be clear what am I going to teach in this article. The example will make it clear what I mean by this title.
Take this sentence:
1) I could not understand what you just said.
2) Which fruit you want, point your finger to that
3) When you come I feel happy
4) what is in your mind, tell me that.
Here we used the words ‚Äúwhat‚Äù,‚Äù Which‚Äù,‚Äù When‚Äù,‚Äù what‚Äù. These are words used for WH-questions. But here they are not exactly used for questions.
Here sentences have two parts ‚Äúcondition‚Äù and ‚Äúpost-condition‚Äù. WH-question words are used to specify the ‚Äúcondition‚Äù part.
It is analogous to ‚Äúif-then‚Äù sentences.

title: Working with nouns - Gender & Plurals in Marathi
content: Working with nouns - Gender & Plurals in Marathi
intro: In Marathi, non-living objects can be masculine or feminine. Gender is not rule-based. Plural forms depend on gender and ending vowel.

blocks.heading: Introduction
blocks.content:
In English, non-living objects are neuter. In Marathi: ‡§Ü‡§Ç‡§¨‡§æ (AMbA) (mango) is masculine, ‡§∏‡§ø‡§ó‡§∞‡•á‡§ü (sigareT) (cigarette) is feminine, ‡§™‡§æ‡§® (pAn) (leaf) is neuter. There are no specific rules for gender‚Äîlearn as you go.

For words not matching rules, singular and plural are same (e.g. ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§† - ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§† (mATh - mATh)).

blocks.heading: Note
